SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Escalus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Of Gouernment, the properties to vn-fold,
Would ſeeme in me t’ affect ſpeech & discourse,
Since I am put to know, that your owne Science
Exceedes (in that) the lists of all aduice
My ſtrength can giue you: Then no more remaines
But that, to your ſufficiency, as your worth is able,
And let them worke: The nature of our People,
Our Cities Institutions, and the Termes
For Common Iustice, y'are as pregnant in
As Art, and practise, hath inriched any
That we remember: There is our Commiſſion,
From which, we would not haue you warpe; call hither,
I ſay, bid come before vs Angelo:
What figure of vs thinke you, he will beare.
For you must know, we haue with ſpeciall ſoule
Elected him our absence to ſupply;
Lent him our terror, drest him with our loue,
And giuen his Deputation all the Organs
Of our owne powre: What thinke you of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: If any in Vienna be of worth
To vndergœ ſuch ample grace, and honour,
It is Lord Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke where he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Alwayes obedient to your Graces will,
I come to know your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Angelo:
There is a kinde of Character in thy life,
That to th’ obseruer, doth thy history
Fully vnfold: Thy ſelfe, and thy belongings
Are not thine owne ſo proper, as to waste
Thy ſelfe vpon thy vertues; they on thee:
Heauen doth with vs, as we, with Torches doe,
Not light them for themselues: For if our vertues
Did not goe forth of vs, 'twere all alike
As if we had them not: Spirits are not finely touch’d,
But to fine iſſues: nor nature neuer lends
The ſmallest ſcruple of her excellence,
But like a thrifty goddeſſe, ſhe determines
Her ſelfe the glory of a creditour,
Both thanks, and vse; but I do bend my ſpeech
To one that can my part in him aduertise;
Hold therefore Angelo:
In our remoue, be thou at full, our ſelfe:
Mortallitie and Mercie in Vienna
Liue in thy tongue, and heart: Old Escalus
Though first in question, is thy ſecondary.
Take thy Commiſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Now good my Lord
Let there be ſome more test, made of my mettle,
Before ſo noble, and ſo great a figure
Be ſtamp't vpon it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: No more euasion:
We haue with a leauen’d, and prepared choice
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honors:
Our haste from hence is of ſo quicke condition,
That it prefers it ſelfe, and leaues vnquestion’d
Matters of needfull value: We ſhall write to you
As time, and our concernings ſhall importune,
How it goes with vs, and doe looke to know
What doth befall you here. So fare you well:
To th’ hopefull execution doe I leaue you,
Of your Commiſſions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet giue leaue (my Lord,)
That we may bring you ſomething on the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: My haste may not admit it,
Nor neede you (on mine honor) haue to doe
With any ſcruple: your ſcope is as mine owne,
So to inforce, or qualifie the Lawes
As to your ſoule ſeemes good: Giue me your hand,
Ile priuily away: I loue the people,
But doe not like to ſtage me to their eyes:
Though it doe well, I doe not rellish well
Their lowd applause, and Aues vehement:
Nor doe I thinke the man of ſafe discretion
That do's affect it. Once more fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: The heauens giue ſafety to your purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Lead forth, and bring you backe in happi-neſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you, fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall desire you, Sir, to giue me leaue
To haue free ſpeech with you; and it concernes me
To looke into the bottome of my place:
A powre I haue, but of what ſtrength and nature,
I am not yet instructed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſo with me: Let vs with-draw together,
And we may ſoone our ſatisfaction haue
Touching that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc
SPEECH.LINE: Ile wait vpon your honor.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Lucio, and two other Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: If the Duke, with the other Dukes, come not to composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the Dukes fall vpon the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen grant vs its peace, but not the King of Hungaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou conclud'st like the Sanctimonious Pirat, that went to ſea with the ten Commandements, but ſcrap’d one out of the Table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt not Steale?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I, that he raz’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? 'twas a commandement, to command the Captaine and all the rest from their functions: they put forth to ſteale: There's not a Souldier of vs all, that in the thanks-giuing before meate, do rallish the petition well, that praies for peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer heard any Souldier dislike it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I beleeue thee: for I thinke thou neuer was't where Grace was ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: No? a dozen times at least.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: What? In meeter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: In any proportion: or in any language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke, or in any Religion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I, why not? Grace, is Grace, despight of all con-trouersie: as for example; Thou thy ſelfe art a wicked villaine, despight of all Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: there went but a paire of ſheeres be-tweene vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I grant: as there may betweene the Lists, and the Veluet. Thou art the List.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: And thou the Veluet; thou art good veluet; thou'rt a three pild-peece I warrant thee: I had as liefe be a Lyst of an English Kersey, as be pil’d, as thou art pil’d, for a French Veluet. Do I ſpeake feelingly now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke thou do'st: and indeed with mo’t pain-full feeling of thy ſpeech: I will, out of thine owne con-feſſion, learne to begin thy health; but, whilst I liue for-get to drinke after thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: I think I haue done my ſelfe wrong, haue I not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, that thou hast; whether thou art tainted, or free.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Behold, behold, where Madam Mitigation comes.
I haue purchas’d as many diseases vnder her Roofe,
As come to

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: To what, I pray?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: To three thousand Dollours a yeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: A French crowne more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art alwayes figuring diseases in me; but thou art full of error, I am ſound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, not (as one would ſay) healthy: but ſo ſound, as things that are hollow; thy bones are hollow; Impiety has made a feast of thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, which of your hips has the mo’t profound Ciatica?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, well: there's one yonder arrested, and carried to prison, was worth fiue thousand of you all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's that I pray'thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, that’s Claudio, Signior Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Claudio to prison? ‘tis not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but I know ‘tis ſo: I ſaw him arrested: ſaw him carried away: and which is more, within these three daies his head to be chop’d off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: But, after all this fooling, I would not haue it ſo:
Art thou ſure of this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: I am too ſure of it: and it is for getting Madam
Iulietta with childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me this may be: he promis’d to meete me two howres ſince, and he was euer precise in promise keeping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 2.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: Besides you know, it drawes ſomthing neere to the ſpeech we had to ſuch a purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Gent.
SPEECH.LINE: But mo’t of all agreeing with the proclamatio[n].

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc
SPEECH.LINE: Away: let's goe learne the truth of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus, what with the war; what with the ſweat, what with the gallowes, and what with pouerty, I am Custom-shrunke. How now? what’s the newes with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Yonder man is carried to prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baw.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: what has he done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A Woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baw.
SPEECH.LINE: But what’s his offence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Groping for Trowts, in a peculiar Riuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baw.
SPEECH.LINE: What? is there a maid with child by him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No: but there's a woman with maid by him: you haue not heard of the proclamation, haue you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baw.
SPEECH.LINE: What proclamation, man?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: All howses in the Suburbs of Vienna must bee pluck’d downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: And what ſhall become of those in the Citie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall ſtand for ſeed: they had gon down to, but that a wise Burger put in for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhall all our houses of resort in the Sub-urbs be puld downe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: To the ground, Mistris.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: Why heere's a change indeed in the Common-wealth: what ſhall become of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Come: feare not you; good Counsellors lacke no Clients: though you change your place, you neede not change your Trade: Ile bee your Tapster ſtill; cou-rage, there will bee pitty taken on you; you that haue worne your eyes almost out in the ſeruice, you will bee considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: What's to doe heere, Thomas Tapster? let's withdraw?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the Prouost to prison: and there's Madam Iuliet.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Prouost, Claudio, Iuliet, Officers, Lucio, & 2.Gent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Fellow, why do'st thou ſhow me thus to th’ world?
Beare me to prison, where I am committed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I do it not in euill disposition,
But from Lord Angelo by ſpeciall charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus can the demy-god (Authority)
Make vs pay downe, for our offence, by waight
The words of heauen; on whom it will, it will,
On whom it will not (sœ) yet ſtill ‘tis iust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Claudio? whence comes this re-straint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: From too much liberty, (my Lucio) Liberty
As ſurfet is the father of much fast,
So euery Scope by the immoderate vse
Turnes to restraint: Our Natures doe pursue
Like Rats that rauyn downe their proper Bane,
A thirsty euill, and when we drinke, we die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: If I could ſpeake ſo wisely vnder an arrest, I would ſend for certaine of my Creditors: and yet, to ſay the truth, I had as lief haue the foppery of freedome, as the mortality of imprisonment: what’s thy offence, Claudio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: What (but to ſpeake of) would offend againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: What, is't murder?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Lecherie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Call it ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Away, Sir, you must goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: One word, good friend:
Lucio, a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: A hundred:
If they'll doe you any good: Is Lechery ſo look’d after?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus ſtands it with me: vpon a true contract
I got poſſeſſion of Iulietas bed,
You know the Lady, ſhe is fast my wife,
Saue that we doe the denunciation lacke
Of outward Order. This we came not to,
Onely for propogation of a Dowre
Remaining in the Coffer of her friends,
From whom we thought it meet to hide our Loue
Till Time had made them for vs. But it chances
The ſtealth of our mo’t mutuall entertainment
With Character too groſſe, is writ on Iuliet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: With childe, perhaps?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnhappely, euen ſo.
And the new Deputie, now for the Duke,
Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newnes,
Or whether that the body publique, be
A horse whereon the Gouernor doth ride,
Who newly in the Seate, that it may know
He can command; lets it ſtrait feele the ſpur:
Whether the Tirranny be in his place,
Or in his Eminence that fills it vp
I ſtagger in: But this new Gouernor
Awakes me all the inrolled penalties
Which haue (like vn-scowr’d Armor) hung by th’ wall
So long, that ninteene Zodiacks haue gone round,
And none of them beene worne; and for a name
Now puts the drowsie and neglected Act
Freshly on me: ‘tis ſurely for a name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant it is: And thy head ſtands ſo tickle on thy ſhoulders, that a milke-maid, if ſhe be in loue, may ſigh it off: Send after the Duke, and appeale to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue done ſo, but hee's not to be found.
I pre'thee (Lucio) doe me this kinde ſeruice:
This day, my ſister ſhould the Cloyster enter,
And there receiue her approbation.
Acquaint her with the danger of my ſtate,
Implore her, in my voice, that ſhe make friends
To the ſtrict deputie: bid her ſelfe aſſay him,
I haue great hope in that: for in her youth
There is a prone and ſpeechleſſe dialect,
Such as moue men: beside, ſhe hath prosperous Art
When ſhe will play with reason, and discourse,
And well ſhe can perswade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray ſhee may; aswell for the encouragement of the like, which else would ſtand vnder greeuous im-position: as for the enioying of thy life, who I would be ſorry ſhould bee thus foolishly lost, at a game of ticke-tacke: Ile to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you good friend Lucio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Within two houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla
SPEECH.LINE: Come Officer, away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: No: holy Father, throw away that thought,
Beleeue not that the dribling dart of Loue
Can pierce a compleat bosome: why, I desire thee
To giue me ſecret harbour, hath a purpose
More graue, and wrinkled, then the aimes, and ends
Of burning youth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: May your Grace ſpeake of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: My holy Sir, none better knowes then you
How I haue euer lou’d the life remoued
And held in idle price, to haunt aſſemblies
Where youth, and cost, witleſſe brauery keepes.
I haue deliuerd to Lord Angelo
(A man of ſtricture and firme abstinence)
My absolute power, and place here in Vienna,
And he ſupposes me trauaild to Poland,
(For ſo I haue ſtrewd it in the common eare)
And ſo it is receiu’d: Now (pious Sir)
You will demand of me, why I do this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: Gladly, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue ſtrict Statutes, and mo’t biting Laws,
(The needfull bits and curbes to headstrong weedes,)
Which for this foureteene yeares, we haue let ſlip,
Euen like an ore-growne Lyon in a Caue
That goes not out to prey: Now, as fond Fathers,
Hauing bound vp the threatning twigs of birch,
Onely to ſticke it in their childrens ſight,
For terror, not to vse: in time the rod
More mock’d, then fear’d: ſo our Decrees,
Dead to infliction, to themselues are dead,
And libertie, plucks Iustice by the nose;
The Baby beates the Nurse, and quite athwart
Goes all decorum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fri.
SPEECH.LINE: It rested in your Grace
To vnloose this tyde-vp Iustice, when you pleas’d:
And it in you more dreadfull would haue ſeem’d
Then in Lord Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe feare: too dreadfull:
Sith 'twas my fault, to giue the people ſcope,
'Twould be my tirrany to ſtrike and gall them,
For what I bid them doe: For, we bid this be done
When euill deedes haue their permiſſiue paſſe,
And not the punishment: therefore indeede (my father)
I haue on Angelo impos’d the office,
Who may in th’ ambush of my name, ſtrike home,
And yet, my nature neuer in the ſight
To do in ſlander: And to behold his ſway
I will, as 'twere a brother of your Order,
Visit both Prince, and People: Therefore I pre'thee
Supply me with the habit, and instruct me
How I may formally in person beare
Like a true Frier: Mœ reasons for this action
At our more leysure, ſhall I render you;
Onely, this one: Lord Angelo is precise,
Stands at a guard with Enuie: ſcarce confeſſes
That his blood flowes: or that his appetite
Is more to bread then ſtone: hence ſhall we ſee
If power change purpose: what our Seemers be.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Isabell and Francisca a Nun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: And haue you Nuns no farther priuiledges?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nun.
SPEECH.LINE: Are not these large enough?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes truely; I ſpeake not as desiring more,
But rather wishing a more ſtrict restraint
Vpon the Sisterhood, the Votarists of Saint Clare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoa? peace be in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's that which cals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nun.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a mans voice: gentle Isabella
Turne you the key, and know his busineſſe of him;
You may; I may not: you are yet vnsworne:
When you haue vowd, you must not ſpeake with men,
But in the presence of the Prioreſſe;
Then if you ſpeake, you must not ſhow your face;
Or if you ſhow your face, you must not ſpeake.
He cals againe: I pray you answere him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace and prosperitie: who is't that cals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile Virgin, (if you be) as those cheeke-Roses
Proclaime you are no leſſe: can you ſo ſteed me,
As bring me to the ſight of Isabella,
A Nouice of this place, and the faire Sister
To her vnhappie brother Claudio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Why her vnhappy Brother? Let me aske,
The rather for I now must make you know
I am that Isabella, and his Sister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle & faire: your Brother kindly greets you;
Not to be weary with you; he's in prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Wœ me; for what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: For that, which if my ſelfe might be his Iudge,
He ſhould receiue his punishment, in thankes:
He hath got his friend with childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, make me not your ſtorie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis true; I would not, though ‘tis my familiar ſin,
With Maids to ſeeme the Lapwing, and to iest
Tongue, far from heart: play with all Virgins ſo:
I hold you as a thing en-skied, and ſainted,
By your renouncement, an imortall ſpirit
And to be talk’d with in ſincerity,
As with a Saint.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: You doe blaspheme the good, in mocking me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe not beleeue it: fewnes, and truth; tis thus,
Your brother, and his louer haue embrac’d;
As those that feed, grow full: as bloſſoming Time
That from the ſeednes, the bare fallow brings
To teeming foyson: euen ſo her plenteous wombe
Expreſſeth his full Tilth, and husbandry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Some one with childe by him? my cosen Iuliet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe your cosen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Adoptedly, as ſchoole-maids change their names
By vaine, though apt affection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: She it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, let him marry her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the point.
The Duke is very ſtrangely gone from hence;
Bore many gentlemen (my ſelfe being one)
In hand, and hope of action: but we doe learne,
By those that know the very Nerues of State,
His giuing-out, were of an infinite distance
From his true meant designe: vpon his place,
(And with full line of his authority)
Gouernes Lord Angelo; A man, whose blood
Is very ſnow-broth: one, who neuer feeles
The wanton ſtings, and motions of the ſence;
But doth rebate, and blunt his naturall edge
With profits of the minde: Studie, and fast
He (to giue feare to vse, and libertie,
Which haue, for long, run-by the hideous law,
As Myce, by Lyons) hath pickt out an act,
Vnder whose heauy ſence, your brothers life
Fals into forfeit: he arrests him on it,
And followes close the rigor of the Statute
To make him an example: all hope is gone,
Vnleſſe you haue the grace, by your faire praier
To ſoften Angelo: And that’s my pith of busineſſe
'Twixt you, and your poore brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth he ſo,
Seeke his life?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Has censur’d him already,
And as I heare, the Prouost hath a warrant
For's execution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas: what poore
Abilitie's in me, to doe him good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Aſſay the powre you haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: My power? alas, I doubt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Our doubts are traitors
And makes vs loose the good we oft might win,
By fearing to attempt: Goe to Lord Angelo
And let him learne to know, when Maidens ſue
Men giue like gods: but when they weepe and kneele,
All their petitions, are as freely theirs
As they themselues would owe them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile ſee what I can doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſpeedily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I will about it ſtrait;
No longer ſtaying, but to giue the Mother
Notice of my affaire: I humbly thanke you:
Commend me to my brother: ſoone at night
Ile ſend him certaine word of my ſucceſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I take my leaue of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſir, adieu.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Angelo, Escalus, and ſeruants, Iustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: We must not make a ſcar-crow of the Law,
Setting it vp to feare the Birds of prey,
And let it keepe one ſhape, till custome make it
Their pearch, and not their terror.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but yet
Let vs be keene, and rather cut a little
Then fall, and bruise to death: alas, this gentleman
Whom I would ſaue, had a mo’t noble father,
Let but your honour know
(Whom I beleeue to be mo’t ſtrait in vertue)
That in the working of your owne affections,
Had time coheard with Place, or place with wishing,
Or that the resolute acting of our blood
Could haue attaind th’ effect of your owne purpose,
Whether you had not ſometime in your life
Er’d in this point, which now you censure him,
And puld the Law vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis one thing to be tempted (Escalus)
Another thing to fall: I not deny
The Iury paſſing on the Prisoners life
May in the ſworne-twelue haue a thiefe, or two
Guiltier then him they try; what’s open made to Iustice,
That Iustice ceizes; What knowes the Lawes
That theeues do paſſe on theeues? ‘Tis very pregnant,
The Iewell that we finde, we ſtoope, and take't,
Because we ſee it; but what we doe not ſee,
We tread vpon, and neuer thinke of it.
You may not ſo extenuate his offence,
For I haue had ſuch faults; but rather tell me
When I, that censure him, do ſo offend,
Let mine owne Iudgement patterne out my death,
And nothing come in partiall. Sir, he must dye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Be it as your wisedome will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the Prouost?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Here if it like your honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: See that Claudio
Be executed by nine to morrow morning,
Bring him his Confeſſor, let him be prepar’d,
For that’s the vtmost of his pilgrimage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: heauen forgiue him; and forgiue vs all:
Some rise by ſinne, and ſome by vertue fall:
Some run from brakes of Ice, and answere none,
And ſome condemned for a fault alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, bring them away: if these be good peo-ple in a Common-weale, that doe nothing but vse their abuses in common houses, I know no law: bring them away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Sir, what’s your name? And what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: If it please your honour, I am the poore Dukes Constable, and my name is Elbow; I doe leane vpon Iu-stice Sir, and doe bring in here before your good honor, two notorious Benefactors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Benefactors? Well: What Benefactors are they?
Are they not Malefactors?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: If it please your honour, I know not well what they are: But precise villaines they are, that I am ſure of, and void of all prophanation in the world, that good Christians ought to haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: This comes off well: here's a wise Officer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe to: What quality are they of? Elbow is your name? Why do'st thou not ſpeake Elbow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: He cannot Sir: he's out at Elbow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: What are you Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: He Sir: a Tapster Sir: parcell Baud: one that ſerues a bad woman: whose house Sir was (as they ſay) pluckt downe in the Suborbs: and now ſhee profeſſes a hot-house; which, I thinke is a very ill house too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: How know you that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: My wife Sir? whom I detest before heauen, and your honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: How? thy wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir: whom I thanke heauen is an honeſt wo-man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Do'st thou detest her therefore?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſay ſir, I will detest my ſelfe also, as well as ſhe, that this house, if it be not a Bauds house, it is pitty of her life, for it is a naughty house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: How do'st thou know that, Constable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, by my wife, who, if ſhe had bin a wo-man Cardinally giuen, might haue bin accus’d in forni-cation, adultery, and all vncleanlineſſe there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: By the womans meanes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, by Mistris Ouer-dons meanes: but as ſhe ſpit in his face, ſo ſhe defide him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, if it please your honor, this is not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Proue it before these varlets here, thou honora-ble man, proue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you heare how he misplaces?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſhe came in great with childe: and longing (sauing your honors reuerence) for ſtewd prewyns; ſir, we had but two in the house, which at that very distant time ſtood, as it were in a fruit dish (a dish of ſome three pence; your honours haue ſeene ſuch dishes) they are not China-dishes, but very good dishes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too: go too: no matter for the dish ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: No indeede ſir not of a pin; you are therein in the right: but, to the point: As I ſay, this Mistris Elbow, being (as I ſay) with childe, and being great bellied, and longing (as I ſaid) for prewyns: and hauing but two in the dish (as I ſaid) Master Froth here, this very man, ha-uing eaten the rest (as I ſaid) & (as I ſay) paying for them very honestly: for, as you know Master Froth, I could not giue you three pence againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fro.
SPEECH.LINE: No indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well: you being then (if you be remem-bred) cracking the ſtones of the foresaid prewyns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fro.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſo I did indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, very well: I telling you then (if you be remembred) that ſuch a one, and ſuch a one, were past cure of the thing you wot of, vnleſſe they kept very good diet, as I told you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fro.
SPEECH.LINE: All this is true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why very well then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come: you are a tedious foole: to the purpose: what was done to Elbowes wife, that hee hath cause to complaine of? Come me to what was done to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, your honor cannot come to that yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſir, nor I meane it not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, but you ſhall come to it, by your honours leaue: And I beseech you, looke into Master Froth here ſir, a man of foure-score pound a yeare; whose father died at Hallowmas: Was't not at Hallowmas Master Froth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fro.
SPEECH.LINE: Allhallond-Eue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why very well: I hope here be truthes: he Sir, ſitting (as I ſay) in a lower chaire, Sir, 'twas in the bunch of Grapes, where indeede you haue a delight to ſit, haue you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fro.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſo, because it is an open roome, and good for winter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why very well then: I hope here be truthes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: This will last out a night in Ruſſia
When nights are longest there: Ile take my leaue,
And leaue you to the hearing of the cause;
Hoping youle finde good cause to whip them all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke no leſſe: good morrow to your Lord-ship. Now Sir, come on: What was done to Elbowes wife, once more?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Once Sir? there was nothing done to her once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you Sir, aske him what this man did to my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech your honor, aske me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſir, what did this Gentleman to her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech you ſir, looke in this Gentlemans face: good Master Froth looke vpon his honor; ‘tis for a good purpose: doth your honor marke his face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, very well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I beseech you marke it well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, I doe ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Doth your honor ſee any harme in his face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be ſupposd vpon a booke, his face is the worst thing about him: good then: if his face be the worst thing about him, how could Master Froth doe the Con-stables wife any harme? I would know that of your honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: He's in the right (Constable) what ſay you to it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: First, and it like you, the house is a respected house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his Mistris is a respected woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: By this hand Sir, his wife is a more respected per-son then any of vs all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Varlet, thou lyest; thou lyest wicked varlet: the time is yet to come that ſhee was euer respected with man, woman, or childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, ſhe was respected with him, before he mar-ried with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the wiser here; Iustice or Iniquitie? Is this true?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: O thou caytiffe: O thou varlet: O thou wick-ed Hanniball; I respected with her, before I was married to her? If euer I was respected with her, or ſhe with me, let not your worship thinke mee the poore Dukes Offi-cer: proue this, thou wicked Hanniball, or ile haue mine action of battry on thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: If he tooke you a box o'th’ eare, you might haue your action of ſlander too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry I thanke your good worship for it: what is't your Worships pleasure I ſhall doe with this wick-ed Caitiffe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly Officer, because he hath ſome offences in him, that thou wouldst discouer, if thou couldst, let him continue in his courses, till thou knowst what they are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry I thanke your worship for it: Thou ſeest thou wicked varlet now, what’s come vpon thee. Thou art to continue now thou Varlet, thou art to continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Where were you borne, friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Froth.
SPEECH.LINE: Here in Vienna, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you of fourescore pounds a yeere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Froth.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, and't please you ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: So: what trade are you of, ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A Tapster, a poore widdowes Tapster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Mistris name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Mistris Ouer-don.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath ſhe had any more then one husband?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Nine, ſir: Ouer-don by the last.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Nine? come hether to me, Master Froth; Master Froth, I would not haue you acquainted with Tapsters; they will draw you Master Froth, and you wil hang them: get you gon, and let me heare no more of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fro.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your worship: for mine owne part, I neuer come into any roome in a Tap-house, but I am drawne in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: no more of it Master Froth: farewell:
Come you hether to me, Mr. Tapster: what’s your name
Mr. Tapster?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: What else?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Bum, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you, ſo that in the beastliest ſence, you are Pompey the great; Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey; howso-euer you colour it in being a Tapster, are you not? come, tell me true, it ſhall be the better for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly ſir, I am a poore fellow that would liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: How would you liue Pompey? by being a bawd? what doe you thinke of the trade Pompey? is it a lawfull trade?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If the Law would allow it, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: But the Law will not allow it Pompey; nor it ſhall not be allowed in Vienna.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Do's your Worship meane to geld and ſplay all the youth of the City?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: No, Pompey.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely Sir, in my poore opinion they will too't then: if your worship will take order for the drabs and the knaues, you need not to feare the bawds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: There is pretty orders beginning I can tell you:
It is but heading, and hanging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If you head, and hang all that offend that way but for ten yeare together; you'll be glad to giue out a Commiſſion for more heads: if this law hold in Vienna ten yeare, ile rent the fairest house in it after three pence a Bay: if you liue to ſee this come to paſſe, ſay Pompey told you ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Thanke you good Pompey; and in requitall of your prophesie, harke you: I aduise you let me not finde you before me againe vpon any complaint whatsœuer; no, not for dwelling where you doe: if I doe Pompey, I ſhall beat you to your Tent, and proue a ſhrewd Caesar to you: in plaine dealing Pompey, I ſhall haue you whipt; ſo for this time, Pompey, fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your Worship for your good counsell; but I ſhall follow it as the flesh and fortune ſhall better determine. Whip me? no, no, let Carman whip his Iade, The valiant heart's not whipt out of his trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hether to me, Master Elbow: come hither Master Constable: how long haue you bin in this place of Constable?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Seuen yeere, and a halfe ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I thought by the readineſſe in the office, you had continued in it ſome time: you ſay ſeauen yeares toge-ther. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: And a halfe ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, it hath beene great paines to you: they do you wrong to put you ſo oft vpon't. Are there not men in your Ward ſufficient to ſerue it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith ſir, few of any wit in ſuch matters: as they are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; I do it for ſome peece of money, and goe through with all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke you bring mee in the names of ſome ſixe or ſeuen, the mo’t ſufficient of your parish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: To your Worships house ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: To my house: fare you well: what’s a clocke, thinke you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iust.
SPEECH.LINE: Eleuen, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you home to dinner with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iust.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: It grieues me for the death of Claudio
But there's no remedie:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iust.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Angelo is ſeuere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: It is but needfull.
Mercy is not it ſelfe, that oft lookes ſo,
Pardon is ſtill the nurse of ſecond wœ:
But yet, poore Claudio; there is no remedie.
Come Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's hearing of a Cause; he will come ſtraight,
I'le tell him of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Pray you doe; Ile know
His pleasure, may be he will relent; alas
He hath but as offended in a dreame,
All Sects, all Ages ſmack of this vice, and he
To die for't?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Now, what’s the matter Prouost?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it your will Claudio ſhall die to morrow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order?
Why do'st thou aske againe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Lest I might be too rash:
Vnder your good correction I haue ſeene
When after execution, Iudgement hath
Repented ore his doome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe to; let that be mine,
Doe you your office, or giue vp your Place,
And you ſhall well be ſpar’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I craue your Honours pardon:
What ſhall be done Sir, with the groaning Iuliet?
Shee's very neere her howre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Dispose of her
To ſome more fitter place; and that with ſpeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Here is the ſister of the man condemn’d,
Desires acceſſe to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he a Sister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord, a very vertuous maid,
And to be ſhortlie of a Sister-hood,
If not alreadie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: let her be admitted,
See you the Fornicatreſſe be remou’d,
Let her haue needfull, but not lauish meanes,
There ſhall be order for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Saue your Honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay a little while: y'are welcome: what’s your will?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a wofull Sutor to your Honour,
'Please but your Honor heare me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: what’s your ſuite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a vice that mo’t I doe abhorre,
And mo’t desire ſhould meet the blow of Iustice;
For which I would not plead, but that I must,
For which I must not plead, but that I am
At warre, twixt will, and will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a brother is condemn’d to die,
I doe beseech you let it be his fault,
And not my brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen giue thee mouing graces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Condemne the fault, and not the actor of it,
Why euery fault's condemnd ere it be done:
Mine were the verie Cipher of a Function
To fine the faults, whose fine ſtands in record,
And let goe by the Actor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh iust, but ſeuere Law:
I had a brother then; heauen keepe your honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue't not ore ſo: to him againe, entreat him,
Kneele downe before him, hang vpon his gowne,
You are too cold: if you ſhould need a pin,
You could not with more tame a tongue desire it:
To him, I ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Must he needs die?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Maiden, no remedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes: I doe thinke that you might pardon him,
And neither heauen, nor man grieue at the mercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not doe't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: But can you if you would?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke what I will not, that I cannot doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: But might you doe't & do the world no wrong
If ſo your heart were touch’d with that remorse,
As mine is to him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee's ſentenc’d, tis too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: You are too cold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Too late? why no: I that doe ſpeak a word
May call it againe: well, beleeue this
No ceremony that to great ones longs,
Not the Kings Crowne; nor the deputed ſword,
The Marshalls Truncheon, nor the Iudges Robe
Become them with one halfe ſo good a grace
As mercie does: If he had bin as you, and you as he,
You would haue ſlipt like him, but he like you
Would not haue beene ſo ſterne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I would to heauen I had your potencie,
And you were Isabell: ſhould it then be thus?
No: I would tell what 'twere to be a Iudge,
And what a prisoner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I, touch him: there's the veine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Brother is a forfeit of the Law,
And you but waste your words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, alas:
Why all the ſoules that were, were forfeit once,
And he that might the vantage best haue tooke,
Found out the remedie: how would you be,
If he, which is the top of Iudgement, ſhould
But iudge you, as you are? Oh, thinke on that,
And mercie then will breathe within your lips
Like man new made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Be you content, (faire Maid)
It is the Law, not I, condemne your brother,
Were he my kinsman, brother, or my ſonne,
It ſhould be thus with him: he must die to morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: To morrow? oh, that’s ſodaine,
Spare him, ſpare him:
Hee's not prepar’d for death; euen for our kitchins
We kill the fowle of ſeason: ſhall we ſerue heauen
With leſſe respect then we doe minister
To our groſſe-selues? good, good my Lord, bethink you;
Who is it that hath di’d for this offence?
There's many haue committed it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I, well ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: The Law hath not bin dead, thogh it hath ſlept
Those many had not dar’d to doe that euill
If the first, that did th’ Edict infringe
Had anſwer’d for his deed. Now ‘tis awake,
Takes note of what is done, and like a Prophet
Lookes in a glaſſe that ſhewes what future euils
Either now, or by remiſſeneſſe, new conceiu’d,
And ſo in progreſſe to be hatch’d, and borne,
Are now to haue no ſucceſſiue degrees,
But here they liue to end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet ſhew ſome pittie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhew it mo’t of all, when I ſhow Iustice;
For then I pittie those I doe not know,
Which a dismis’d offence, would after gaule
And doe him right, that answering one foule wrong
Liues not to act another. Be ſatisfied;
Your Brother dies to morrow; be content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: So you must be y first that giues this ſentence,
And hee, that ſuffers: Oh, it is excellent
To haue a Giants ſtrength: but it is tyrannous
To vse it like a Giant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That's well ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Could great men thunder
As Ioue himselfe do's, Ioue would neuer be quiet,
For euery pelting petty Officer
Would vse his heauen for thunder;
Nothing but thunder: Mercifull heauen,
Thou rather with thy ſharpe and ſulpherous bolt
Splits the vn-wedgable and gnarled Oke,
Then the ſoft Mertill: But man, proud man,
Drest in a little briefe authoritie,
Mo’t ignorant of what he's mo’t aſſur’d,
(His glaſſie Eſſence) like an angry Ape
Plaies ſuch phantastique tricks before high heauen,
As makes the Angels weepe: who with our ſpleenes,
Would all themselues laugh mortall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, to him, to him wench: he will relent,
Hee's comming: I perceiue't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray heauen ſhe win him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: We cannot weigh our brother with our ſelfe,
Great men may iest with Saints: tis wit in them,
But in the leſſe fowle prophanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou'rt i'th right (Girle) more o'that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: That in the Captaine's but a chollericke word,
Which in the Souldier is flat blasphemie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Art auis’d o'that? more on't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Why doe you put these ſayings vpon me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Because Authoritie, though it erre like others,
Hath yet a kinde of medicine in it ſelfe
That ſkins the vice o'th top; goe to your bosome,
Knock there, and aske your heart what it doth know
That's like my brothers fault: if it confeſſe
A naturall guiltineſſe, ſuch as is his,
Let it not ſound a thought vpon your tongue
Against my brothers life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee ſpeakes, and ‘tis ſuch ſence
That my Sence breeds with it; fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle my Lord, turne backe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I will bethinke me: come againe to morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Hark, how Ile bribe you: good my Lord turn back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: How? bribe me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Is.
SPEECH.LINE: I, with ſuch gifts that heauen ſhall ſhare with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: You had mar’d all else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Not with fond Sickles of the tested-gold,
Or Stones, whose rate are either rich, or poore
As fancie values them: but with true prayers,
That ſhall be vp at heauen, and enter there
Ere Sunne rise: prayers from preserued ſoules,
From fasting Maides, whose mindes are dedicate
To nothing temporall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: come to me to morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe to: ‘tis well; away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen keepe your honour ſafe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.
For I am that way going to temptation,
Where prayers croſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: At what hower to morrow,
Shall I attend your Lordship?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: At any time 'fore-noone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Saue your Honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: From thee: euen from thy vertue.
What's this? what’s this? is this her fault, or mine?
The Tempter, or the Tempted, who ſins mo’t? ha?
Not ſhe: nor doth ſhe tempt: but it is I,
That, lying by the Violet in the Sunne,
Doe as the Carrion do's, not as the flowre,
Corrupt with vertuous ſeason: Can it be,
That Modesty may more betray our Sence
Then womans lightneſſe? hauing waste ground enough,
Shall we desire to raze the Sanctuary
And pitch our euils there? oh fie, fie, fie:
What dost thou? or what art thou Angelo?
Dost thou desire her fowly, for those things
That make her good? oh, let her brother liue:
Theeues for their robbery haue authority,
When Iudges ſteale themselues: what, doe I loue her,
That I desire to heare her ſpeake againe?
And feast vpon her eyes? what is't I dreame on?
Oh cunning enemy, that to catch a Saint,
With Saints dost bait thy hooke: mo’t dangerous
Is that temptation, that doth goad vs on
To ſinne, in louing vertue: neuer could the Strumpet
With all her double vigor, Art, and Nature
Once ſtir my temper: but this vertuous Maid
Subdues me quite: Euer till now
When men were fond, I ſmild, and wondred how.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile to you, Prouost, ſo I thinke you are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I am the Prouost: whats your will, good Frier?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Bound by my charity, and my blest order,
I come to visite the afflicted ſpirits
Here in the prison: doe me the common right
To let me ſee them: and to make me know
The nature of their crimes, that I may minister
To them accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I would do more then that, if more were needfull
Looke here comes one: a Gentlewoman of mine,
Who falling in the flawes of her owne youth,
Hath blisterd her report: She is with childe,
And he that got it, ſentenc’d: a yong man,
More fit to doe another ſuch offence,
Then dye for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: When must he dye?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: As I do thinke to morrow.
I haue prouided for you, ſtay a while
And you ſhall be conducted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Repent you (faire one) of the ſin you carry?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe; and beare the ſhame mo’t patiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile teach you how you ſhal araign your conscie[n]ce
And try your penitence, if it be ſound,
Or hollowly put on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile gladly learne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue you the man that wrong’d you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, as I loue the woman that wrong’d him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: So then it ſeemes your mo’t offence full act
Was mutually committed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Mutually.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Then was your ſin of heauier kinde then his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe confeſſe it, and repent it (Father.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis meet ſo (daughter) but least you do repent
As that the ſin hath brought you to this ſhame,
Which ſorrow is alwaies toward our ſelues, not heauen,
Showing we would not ſpare heauen, as we loue it,
But as we ſtand in feare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe repent me, as it is an euill,
And take the ſhame with ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: There rest:
Your partner (as I heare) must die to morrow,
And I am going with instruction to him:
Grace goe with you, Benedicite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iul.
SPEECH.LINE: Must die to morrow? oh iniurious Loue
That respits me a life, whose very comfort
Is ſtill a dying horror.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis pitty of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: When I would pray, & think, I thinke, and pray
To ſeuerall ſubiects: heauen hath my empty words,
Whilst my Inuention, hearing not my Tongue,
Anchors on Isabell: heauen in my mouth,
As if I did but onely chew his name,
And in my heart the ſtrong and ſwelling euill
Of my conception: the ſtate whereon I ſtudied
Is like a good thing, being often read
Growne feard, and tedious: yea, my Grauitie
Wherein (let no man heare me) I take pride,
Could I, with boote, change for an idle plume
Which the ayre beats for vaine: oh place, oh forme,
How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit
Wrench awe from fooles, and tye the wiser ſoules
To thy false ſeeming? Blood, thou art blood,
Let's write good Angell on the Deuills horne
‘Tis not the Deuills Crest: how now? who's there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: One Isabell, a Sister, desires acceſſe to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Teach her the way: oh, heauens
Why doe's my bloud thus muster to my heart,
Making both it vnable for it ſelfe,
And dispoſſeſſing all my other parts
Of neceſſary fitneſſe?
So play the foolish throngs with one that ſwounds,
Come all to help him, and ſo ſtop the ayre
By which hee ſhould reuiue: and euen ſo
The generall ſubiect to a wel-wisht King
Quit their owne part, and in obsequious fondneſſe
Crowd to his presence, where their vn-taught loue
Must needs appear offence: how now faire Maid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I am come to know your pleasure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: That you might know it, wold much better please me,
Then to demand what ‘tis: your Brother cannot liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo: heauen keepe your Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet may he liue a while: and it may be
As long as you, or I: yet he must die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnder your Sentence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Yea.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: When, I beseech you: that in his Reprieue
(Longer, or ſhorter) he may be ſo fitted
That his ſoule ſicken not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? fie, these filthy vices: It were as good
To pardon him, that hath from nature ſtolne
A man already made, as to remit
Their ſawcie ſweetnes, that do coyne heauens Image
In ſtamps that are forbid: ‘tis all as easie,
Falsely to take away a life true made,
As to put mettle in restrained meanes
To make a false one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis ſet downe ſo in heauen, but not in earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you ſo: then I ſhall poze you quickly.
Which had you rather, that the mo’t iust Law
Now tooke your brothers life, and to redeeme him
Giue vp your body to ſuch ſweet vncleanneſſe
As ſhe that he hath ſtaind?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, beleeue this.
I had rather giue my body, then my ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I talke not of your ſoule: our compel’d ſins
Stand more for number, then for accompt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay Ile not warrant that: for I can ſpeake
Against the thing I ſay: Answere to this,
I (now the voyce of the recorded Law)
Pronounce a ſentence on your Brothers life,
Might there not be a charitie in ſinne,
To ſaue this Brothers life?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Please you to doo't,
Ile take it as a perill to my ſoule,
It is no ſinne at all, but charitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Pleas’d you to doo't, at perill of your ſoule
Were equall poize of ſinne, and charitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: That I do beg his life, if it be ſinne
Heauen let me beare it: you granting of my ſuit,
If that be ſin, Ile make it my Morne-praier,
To haue it added to the faults of mine,
And nothing of your answere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but heare me,
Your ſence pursues not mine: either you are ignorant,
Or ſeeme ſo crafty; and that’s not good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Let be ignorant, and in nothing good,
But graciously to know I am no better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus wisdome wishes to appeare mo’t bright,
When it doth taxe it ſelfe: As these blacke Masques
Proclaime an en-shield beauty ten times louder
Then beauty could displaied: But marke me,
To be receiued plaine, Ile ſpeake more groſſe:
Your Brother is to dye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: So.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: And his offence is ſo, as it appeares,
Accountant to the Law, vpon that paine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: True.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Admit no other way to ſaue his life
(As I ſubscribe not that, nor any other,
But in the loſſe of question) that you, his Sister,
Finding your ſelfe desir’d of ſuch a person,
Whose creadit with the Iudge, or owne great place,
Could fetch your Brother from the Manacles
Of the all-building-Law: and that there were
No earthly meane to ſaue him, but that either
You must lay downe the treasures of your body,
To this ſupposed, or else to let him ſuffer:
What would you doe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: As much for my poore Brother, as my ſelfe;
That is: were I vnder the tearmes of death,
Th’ impreſſion of keene whips, I'ld weare as Rubies,
And ſtrip my ſelfe to death, as to a bed,
That longing haue bin ſicke for, ere I'ld yeeld
My body vp to ſhame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Then must your brother die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: And 'twer the cheaper way:
Better it were a brother dide at once,
Then that a ſister, by redeeming him
Should die for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Were not you then as cruell as the Sentence,
That you haue ſlander’d ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Ignomie in ransome, and free pardon
Are of two houses: lawfull mercie,
Is nothing kin to fowle redemption.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſeem’d of late to make the Law a tirant,
And rather prou’d the ſliding of your brother
A merriment, then a vice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh pardon me my Lord, it oft fals out
To haue, what we would haue,
We ſpeake not what we meane;
I ſomething do excuse the thing I hate,
For his aduantage that I dearely loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: We are all fraile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Else let my brother die,
If not a fedarie but onely he
Owe, and ſucceed thy weakneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, women are fraile too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I, as the glaſſes where they view themselues,
Which are as easie broke as they make formes:
Women? Helpe heauen; men their creation marre
In profiting by them: Nay, call vs ten times fraile,
For we are ſoft, as our complexions are,
And credulous to false prints.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke it well:
And from this testimonie of your owne ſex
(Since I ſuppose we are made to be no ſtronger
Then faults may ſhake our frames) let me be bold;
I do arrest your words. Be that you are,
That is a woman; if you be more, you'r none.
If you be one (as you are well exprest
By all externall warrants) ſhew it now,
By putting on the destin’d Liuerie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no tongue but one; gentle my Lord,
Let me entreate you ſpeake the former language.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Plainlie conceiue I loue you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: My brother did loue Iuliet,
And you tell me that he ſhall die for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall not Isabell if you giue me loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I know your vertue hath a licence in't,
Which ſeemes a little fouler then it is,
To plucke on others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me on mine Honor,
My words expreſſe my purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha? Little honor, to be much beleeu’d,
And mo’t pernitious purpose: Seeming, ſeeming.
I will proclaime thee Angelo, looke for't.
Signe me a present pardon for my brother,
Or with an out-stretcht throate Ile tell the world aloud
What man thou art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Who will beleeue thee Isabell?
My vnsoild name, th’ austeereneſſe of my life,
My vouch against you, and my place i'th State,
Will ſo your accusation ouer-weigh,
That you ſhall ſtifle in your owne report,
And ſmell of calumnie. I haue begun,
And now I giue my ſensuall race, the reine,
Fit thy consent to my ſharpe appetite,
Lay by all nicetie, and prolixious blushes
That banish what they ſue for: Redeeme thy brother,
By yeelding vp thy bodie to my will,
Or else he must not onelie die the death,
But thy vnkindneſſe ſhall his death draw out
To lingring ſufferance: Answer me to morrow,
Or by the affection that now guides me mo’t,
Ile proue a Tirant to him. As for you,
Say what you can; my false, ore-weighs your true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: To whom ſhould I complaine? Did I tell this,
Who would beleeue me? O perilous mouthes
That beare in them, one and the ſelfesame tongue,
Either of condemnation, or approofe,
Bidding the Law make curtsie to their will,
Hooking both right and wrong to th’ appetite,
To follow as it drawes. Ile to my brother,
Though he hath falne by prompture of the blood,
Yet hath he in him ſuch a minde of Honor,
That had he twentie heads to tender downe
On twentie bloodie blockes, hee'ld yeeld them vp,
Before his ſister ſhould her bodie ſtoope
To ſuch abhord pollution.
Then Isabell liue chaste, and brother die;
"More then our Brother, is our Chastitie.
Ile tell him yet of Angelo's request,
And fit his minde to death, for his ſoules rest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: The miserable haue no other medicine But onely hope: I'haue hope to liue, and am prepar’d to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Be absolute for death: either death or life
Shall thereby be the ſweeter. Reason thus with life:
If I do loose thee, I do loose a thing
That none but fooles would keepe: a breath thou art,
Seruile to all the ſkyie-influences
That dost this habitation where thou keepst
Hourely afflict: Meerely, thou art deaths foole,
For him thou labourst by thy flight to ſhun,
And yet runst toward him ſtill. Thou art not noble,
For all th’ accommodations that thou bearst,
Are nurst by baseneſſe: Thou'rt by no meanes valiant,
For thou dost feare the ſoft and tender forke
Of a poore worme: thy best of rest is ſleepe,
And that thou oft prouoakst, yet groſſelie fearst
Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thy ſelfe,
For thou exists on manie a thousand graines
That iſſue out of dust. Happie thou art not,
For what thou hast not, ſtill thou ſtriu'st to get,
And what thou hast forgetst. Thou art not certaine,
For thy complexion ſhifts to ſtrange effects,
After the Moone: If thou art rich, thou'rt poore,
For like an Aſſe, whose backe with Ingots bowes;
Thou bearst thy heauie riches but a iournie,
And death vnloads thee; Friend hast thou none.
For thine owne bowels which do call thee, fire
The meere effusion of thy proper loines
Do curse the Gowt, Sapego, and the Rheume
For ending thee no ſooner. Thou hast nor youth, nor age
But as it were an after-dinners ſleepe
Dreaming on both, for all thy bleſſed youth
Becomes as aged, and doth begge the almes
Of palsied-Eld: and when thou art old, and rich
Thou hast neither heate, affection, limbe, nor beautie
To make thy riches pleasant: what’s yet in this
That beares the name of life? Yet in this life
Lie hid moe thousand deaths; yet death we feare
That makes these oddes, all euen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: I humblie thanke you.
To ſue to liue, I finde I ſeeke to die,
And ſeeking death, finde life: Let it come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa? Peace heere; Grace, and good com-panie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Who's there? Come in, the wish deserues a welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Deere ſir, ere long Ile visit you againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t holie Sir, I thanke you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: My busineſſe is a word or two with Claudio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And verie welcom: looke Signior, here's your ſister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Prouost, a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: As manie as you please.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring them to heare me ſpeak, where I may be conceal’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Now ſister, what’s the comfort?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Why,
As all comforts are: mo’t good, mo’t good indeede,
Lord Angelo hauing affaires to heauen
Intends you for his ſwift Ambaſſador,
Where you ſhall be an euerlasting Leiger;
Therefore your best appointment make with ſpeed,
To Morrow you ſet on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Is there no remedie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: None, but ſuch remedie, as to ſaue a head
To cleaue a heart in twaine:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: But is there anie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes brother, you may liue;
There is a diuellish mercie in the Iudge,
If you'l implore it, that will free your life,
But fetter you till death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Perpetuall durance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I iust, perpetuall durance, a restraint
Through all the worlds vastiditie you had
To a determin’d ſcope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: But in what nature?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a one, as you consenting too't,
Would barke your honor from that trunke you beare,
And leaue you naked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me know the point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I do feare thee Claudio, and I quake,
Least thou a feauorous life ſhouldst entertaine,
And ſix or ſeuen winters more respect
Then a perpetuall Honor. Dar'st thou die?
The ſence of death is mo’t in apprehension,
And the poore Beetle that we treade vpon
In corporall ſufferance, finds a pang as great,
As when a Giant dies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Why giue you me this ſhame?
Thinke you I can a resolution fetch
From flowrie tenderneſſe? If I must die,
I will encounter darkneſſe as a bride,
And hugge it in mine armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: There ſpake my brother: there my fathers graue
Did vtter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die:
Thou art too noble, to conserue a life
In base appliances. This outward ſainted Deputie,
Whose ſetled visage, and deliberate word
Nips youth i'th head, and follies doth emmew
As Falcon doth the Fowle, is yet a diuell:
His filth within being cast, he would appeare
A pond, as deepe as hell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: The prenzie, Angelo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ‘tis the cunning Liuerie of hell,
The damnest bodie to inuest, and couer
In prenzie gardes; dost thou thinke Claudio,
If I would yeeld him my virginitie
Thou might'st be freed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauens, it cannot be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, he would giu't thee; from this rank offence
So to offend him ſtill. This night's the time
That I ſhould do what I abhorre to name,
Or else thou diest to morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt not do't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: O, were it but my life,
I’de throw it downe for your deliuerance
As frankely as a pin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Thankes deere Isabell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Be readie Claudio, for your death to morrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clau.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes. Has he affections in him,
That thus can make him bite the Law by th’ nose,
When he would force it? Sure it is no ſinne,
Or of the deadly ſeuen it is the least.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is the least?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: If it were damnable, he being ſo wise,
Why would he for the momentarie tricke
Be perdurablie fin’de? Oh Isabell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaies my brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Death is a fearefull thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhamed life, a hatefull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but to die, and go we know not where,
To lie in cold obstruction, and to rot,
This ſensible warme motion, to become
A kneaded clod; And the delighted ſpirit
To bath in fierie floods, or to recide
In thrilling Region of thicke-ribbed Ice,
To be imprison’d in the viewleſſe windes
And blowne with restleſſe violence round about
The pendant world: or to be worse then worst
Of those, that lawleſſe and incertaine thought,
Imagine howling, ‘tis too horrible.
The weariest, and mo’t loathed worldly life
That Age, Ache, periury, and imprisonment
Can lay on nature, is a Paradise
To what we feare of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, alas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Sister, let me liue.
What ſinne you do, to ſaue a brothers life,
Nature dispenses with the deede ſo farre,
That it becomes a vertue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh you beast,
Oh faithleſſe Coward, oh dishonest wretch,
Wilt thou be made a man, out of my vice?
Is't not a kinde of Incest, to take life
From thine owne ſisters ſhame? What ſhould I thinke,
Heauen ſhield my Mother plaid my Father faire:
For ſuch a warped ſlip of wilderneſſe
Nere iſſu’d from his blood. Take my defiance,
Die, perish: Might but my bending downe
Repreeue thee from thy fate, it ſhould proceede.
Ile pray a thousand praiers for thy death,
No word to ſaue thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay heare me Isabell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh fie, fie, fie:
Thy ſinn's not accidentall, but a Trade;
Mercy to thee would proue it ſelfe a Bawd,
‘Tis best that thou diest quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heare me Isabella.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Vouchsafe a word, yong ſister, but one word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: What is your Will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Might you dispense with your leysure, I would by and by haue ſome ſpeech with you: the ſatisfaction I would require, is likewise your owne benefit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue no ſuperfluous leysure, my ſtay must be ſtolen out of other affaires: but I will attend you a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Son, I haue ouer-heard what hath past between you & your ſister. Angelo had neuer the purpose to cor-rupt her; onely he hath made an aſſay of her vertue, to practise his iudgement with the disposition of natures. She (hauing the truth of honour in her) hath made him that gracious deniall, which he is mo’t glad to receiue: I am Confeſſor to Angelo, and I know this to be true, ther-fore prepare your ſelfe to death: do not ſatisfie your re-solution with hopes that are fallible, to morrow you must die, goe to your knees, and make ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ask my ſister pardon, I am ſo out of loue with life, that I will ſue to be rid of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold you there: farewell: Prouost, a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What's your will (father?)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: That now you are come, you wil be gone: leaue me a while with the Maid, my minde promises with my habit, no loſſe ſhall touch her by my company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro
SPEECH.LINE: In good time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: The hand that hath made you faire, hath made you good: the goodnes that is cheape in beauty, makes beauty briefe in goodnes; but grace being the ſoule of your complexion, ſhall keepe the body of it euer faire: the aſſault that Angelo hath made to you, Fortune hath conuaid to my vnderstanding; and but that frailty hath examples for his falling, I ſhould wonder at Angelo: how will you doe to content this Substitute, and to ſaue your Brother?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I am now going to resolue him: I had rather my brother die by the Law, then my ſonne ſhould be vn-lawfullie borne. But (oh) how much is the good Duke deceiu’d in Angelo: if euer he returne, and I can ſpeake to him, I will open my lips in vaine, or discouer his go-uernment. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſhall not be much amiſſe: yet, as the mat-ter now ſtands, he will auoid your accusation: he made triall of you onelie. Therefore fasten your eare on my aduisings, to the loue I haue in doing good; a remedie presents it ſelfe. I doe make my ſelfe beleeue that you may mo’t vprighteously do a poor wronged Lady a me-rited benefit; redeem your brother from the angry Law; doe no ſtaine to your owne gracious person, and much please the absent Duke, if peraduenture he ſhall euer re-turne to haue hearing of this busineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me heare you ſpeake farther; I haue ſpirit to do any thing that appeares not fowle in the truth of my ſpirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Vertue is bold, and goodnes neuer fearefull: Haue you not heard ſpeake of Mariana the ſister of Fre-dericke the great Souldier, who miscarried at Sea?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue heard of the Lady, and good words went with her name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee ſhould this Angelo haue married: was af-fianced to her oath, and the nuptiall appointed: between which time of the contract, and limit of the ſolemnitie, her brother Fredericke was wrackt at Sea, hauing in that perished veſſell, the dowry of his ſister: but marke how heauily this befell to the poore Gentlewoman, there ſhe lost a noble and renowned brother, in his loue toward her, euer mo’t kinde and naturall: with him the portion and ſinew of her fortune, her marriage dowry: with both, her combynate-husband, this well-seeming Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Can this be ſo? did Angelo ſo leaue her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Left her in her teares, & dried not one of them with his comfort: ſwallowed his vowes whole, preten-ding in her, discoueries of dishonor: in few, bestow’d her on her owne lamentation, which ſhe yet weares for his ſake: and he, a marble to her teares, is washed with them, but relents not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: What a merit were it in death to take this poore maid from the world? what corruption in this life, that it will let this man liue? But how out of this can ſhee a-uaile? _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a rupture that you may easily heale: and the cure of it not onely ſaues your brother, but keepes you from dishonor in doing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Shew me how (good Father.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: This fore-named Maid hath yet in her the con-tinuance of her first affection: his vniust vnkindeneſſe (that in all reason ſhould haue quenched her loue) hath (like an impediment in the Current) made it more vio-lent and vnruly: Goe you to Angelo, answere his requi-ring with a plausible obedience, agree with his demands to the point: onely referre your ſelfe to this aduantage; first, that your ſtay with him may not be long: that the time may haue all ſhadow, and ſilence in it: and the place answere to conuenience: this being granted in course, and now followes all: wee ſhall aduise this wronged maid to ſteed vp your appointment, goe in your place: if the encounter acknowledge it ſelfe heereafter, it may compell him to her recompence; and heere, by this is your brother ſaued, your honor vntainted, the poore Mariana aduantaged, and the corrupt Deputy ſcaled. The Maid will I frame, and make fit for his attempt: if you thinke well to carry this as you may, the doublenes of the benefit defends the deceit from reproofe. What thinke you of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: The image of it giues me content already, and I trust it will grow to a mo’t prosperous perfection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: It lies much in your holding vp: haste you ſpee-dily to Angelo, if for this night he intreat you to his bed, giue him promise of ſatisfaction: I will presently to S[aint]. Lukes, there at the moated-Grange recides this deie-cted Mariana; at that place call vpon me, and dispatch with Angelo, that it may be quickly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I thank you for this comfort: fare you well good father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you will needes buy and ſell men and women like beasts, we ſhall haue all the world drinke browne & white bastard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauens, what ſtuffe is heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Twas neuer merry world ſince of two vsuries the merriest was put downe, and the worser allow’d by order of Law; a fur’d gowne to keepe him warme; and furd with Foxe and Lamb-skins too, to ſignifie, that craft being richer then Innocency, ſtands for the facing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Come your way ſir: 'bleſſe you good Father
Frier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: And you good Brother Father; what offence hath this man made you, Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, he hath offended the Law; and Sir, we take him to be a Theefe too Sir: for wee haue found vpon him Sir, a ſtrange Pick-lock, which we haue ſent to the Deputie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, ſirrah, a Bawd, a wicked bawd,
The euill that thou causest to be done,
That is thy meanes to liue. Do thou but thinke
What ‘tis to cram a maw, or cloath a backe
From ſuch a filthie vice: ſay to thy ſelfe,
From their abhominable and beastly touches
I drinke, I eate away my ſelfe, and liue:
Canst thou beleeue thy liuing is a life,
So ſtinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, it do's ſtinke in ſome ſort, Sir:
But yet Sir I would proue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, if the diuell haue giuen thee proofs for ſin
Thou wilt proue his. Take him to prison Officer:
Correction, and Instruction must both worke
Ere this rude beast will profit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: He must before the Deputy Sir, he ha's giuen him warning: the Deputy cannot abide a Whore-ma-ster: if he be a Whore-monger, and comes before him, he were as good go a mile on his errand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: That we were all, as ſome would ſeeme to bee
From our faults, as faults from ſeeming free.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: His necke will come to your wast, a Cord ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſpy comfort, I cry baile: Here's a Gentleman, and a friend of mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: How now noble Pompey? What, at the wheels of Caesar? Art thou led in triumph? What is there none of Pigmalions Images newly made woman to bee had now, for putting the hand in the pocket, and extracting clutch’d? What reply? Ha? What ſaist thou to this Tune, Matter, and Method? Is't not drown’d i'th last raine? Ha? What ſaist thou Trot? Is the world as it was Man? Which is the way? Is it ſad, and few words? Or how? The tricke of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Still thus, and thus: ſtill worse?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: How doth my deere Morsell, thy Mistris? Pro-cures ſhe ſtill? Ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Troth ſir, ſhee hath eaten vp all her beefe, and ſhe is her ſelfe in the tub.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ‘tis good: It is the right of it: it must be ſo. Euer your fresh Whore, and your pouder’d Baud, an vnshun’d consequence, it must be ſo. Art going to pri-son Pompey?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes faith ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ‘tis not amiſſe Pompey: farewell: goe ſay
I ſent thee thether: for debt Pompey? Or how?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: For being a baud, for being a baud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, then imprison him: If imprisonment be the due of a baud, why ‘tis his right. Baud is he doubt-leſſe, and of antiquity too: Baud borne. Farwell good Pompey: Commend me to the prison Pompey, you will turne good husband now Pompey, you will keepe the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope Sir, your good Worship wil be my baile?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: No indeed wil I not Pompey, it is not the wear: I will pray (Pompey) to encrease your bondage if you take it not patiently: Why, your mettle is the more: Adieu trustie Pompey. Bleſſe you Friar.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: And you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Do's Bridget paint ſtill, Pompey? Ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Come your waies ſir, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: You will not baile me then Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Then Pompey, nor now: what newes abroad Fri-er?
What newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elb.
SPEECH.LINE: Come your waies ſir, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe to kennell (Pompey) goe:
What newes Frier of the Duke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I know none: can you tell me of any?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Some ſay he is with the Emperor of Ruſſia: other ſome, he is in Rome: but where is he thinke you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I know not where: but wheresœuer, I wish him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: It was a mad fantasticall tricke of him to ſteale from the State, and vsurpe the beggerie hee was neuer borne to: Lord Angelo Dukes it well in his absence: he puts transgreſſion too't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: He do's well in't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: A little more lenitie to Lecherie would doe no harme in him: Something too crabbed that way, Frier.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: It is too general a vice, and ſeueritie must cure it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes in good ſooth, the vice is of a great kindred; it is well allied, but it is impoſſible to extirpe it quite, Frier, till eating and drinking be put downe. They ſay this Angelo was not made by Man and Woman, after this downe-right way of Creation: is it true, thinke you?
