SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhould he be made then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Some report, a Sea-maid ſpawn’d him. Some, that he was begot betweene two Stock-fishes. But it is certaine, that when he makes water, his Vrine is con-geal’d ice, that I know to bee true: and he is a motion generatiue, that’s infallible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: You are pleasant ſir, and ſpeake apace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what a ruthleſſe thing is this in him, for the rebellion of a Cod-peece, to take away the life of a man? Would the Duke that is absent haue done this? Ere he would haue hang’d a man for the getting a hun-dred Bastards, he would haue paide for the Nursing a thousand. He had ſome feeling of the ſport, hee knew the ſeruice, and that instructed him to mercie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer heard the absent Duke much detected for Women, he was not enclin’d that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Sir, you are deceiu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis not poſſible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Who, not the Duke? Yes, your beggar of fifty: and his vse was, to put a ducket in her Clack-dish; the Duke had Crochets in him. Hee would be drunke too, that let me informe you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: You do him wrong, ſurely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I was an inward of his: a ſhie fellow was the Duke, and I beleeue I know the cause of his with-drawing. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: What (I prethee) might be the cause?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: No, pardon: ‘Tis a ſecret must bee lockt with-in the teeth and the lippes: but this I can let you vnder-stand, the greater file of the ſubiect held the Duke to be wise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Wise? Why no question but he was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: A very ſuperficiall, ignorant, vnweighing fellow

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Either this is Enuie in you, Folly, or mista-king: The very ſtreame of his life, and the busineſſe he hath helmed, must vppon a warranted neede, giue him a better proclamation. Let him be but testimonied in his owne bringings forth, and hee ſhall appeare to the enuious, a Scholler, a Statesman, and a Soldier: there-fore you ſpeake vnskilfully: or, if your knowledge bee more, it is much darkned in your malice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I know him, and I loue him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue talkes with better knowledge, & know-ledge with deare loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Sir, I know what I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I can hardly beleeue that, ſince you know not what you ſpeake. But if euer the Duke returne (as our praiers are he may) let mee desire you to make your an-swer before him: if it bee honeſt you haue ſpoke, you haue courage to maintaine it; I am bound to call vppon you, and I pray you your name?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir my name is Lucio, wel known to the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall know you better Sir, if I may liue to report you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I feare you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: O, you hope the Duke will returne no more: or you imagine me to vnhurtfull an opposite: but indeed I can doe you little harme: You'll for-sweare this a-gaine? _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be hang’d first: Thou art deceiu’d in mee Friar. But no more of this: Canst thou tell if Claudio die to morrow, or no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſhould he die Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why? For filling a bottle with a Tunne-dish: I would the Duke we talke of were return’d againe: this vngenitur’d Agent will vn-people the Prouince with Continencie. Sparrowes must not build in his house-eeues, because they are lecherous: The Duke yet would haue darke deeds darkelie answered, hee would neuer bring them to light: would hee were return’d. Marrie this Claudio is condemned for vntruſſing. Farwell good Friar, I prethee pray for me: The Duke (I ſay to thee againe) would eate Mutton on Fridaies. He's now past it, yet (and I ſay to thee) hee would mouth with a beg-gar, though ſhe ſmelt browne-bread and Garlicke: ſay that I ſaid ſo: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: No might, nor greatneſſe in mortality
Can censure ſcape: Back-wounding calumnie
The whitest vertue ſtrikes. What King ſo ſtrong,
Can tie the gall vp in the ſlanderous tong?
But who comes heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, away with her to prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord be good to mee, your Honor is accounted a mercifull man: good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Double, and trebble admonition, and ſtill for-feite in the ſame kinde? This would make mercy ſweare and play the Tirant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: A Bawd of eleuen yeares continuance, may it please your Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bawd.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, this is one Lucio's information a-gainst me, Mistris Kate Keepe-downe was with childe by him in the Dukes time, he promis’d her marriage: his Childe is a yeere and a quarter olde come Philip and Ia-cob: I haue kept it my ſelfe; and ſee how hee goes about to abuse me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: That fellow is a fellow of much License: Let him be call’d before vs, Away with her to prison: Goe too, no more words. Prouost, my Brother Angelo will not be alter’d, Claudio must die to morrow: Let him be furnish’d with Diuines, and haue all charitable prepara-tion. If my brother wrought by my pitie, it ſhould not be ſo with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: So please you, this Friar hath beene with him, and aduis’d him for th’ entertainment of death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Good' euen, good Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Bliſſe, and goodneſſe on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Of whence are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Not of this Countrie, though my chance is now
To vse it for my time: I am a brother
Of gracious Order, late come from the Sea,
In ſpeciall busineſſe from his Holineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: What newes abroad i'th World?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: None, but that there is ſo great a Feauor on goodneſſe, that the diſſolution of it must cure it. No-ueltie is onely in request, and as it is as dangerous to be aged in any kinde of course, as it is vertuous to be con-stant in any vndertaking. There is ſcarse truth enough aliue to make Societies ſecure, but Securitie enough to make Fellowships accurst: Much vpon this riddle runs the wisedome of the world: This newes is old enough, yet it is euerie daies newes. I pray you Sir, of what dis-position was the Duke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: One, that aboue all other ſtrifes,
Contended especially to know himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: What pleasure was he giuen to?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Rather reioycing to ſee another merry, then merrie at anie thing which profest to make him reioice. A Gentleman of all temperance. But leaue wee him to his euents, with a praier they may proue prosperous, & let me desire to know, how you finde Claudio prepar’d? I am made to vnderstand, that you haue lent him visita-tion. _

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: He profeſſes to haue receiued no ſinister mea-sure from his Iudge, but mo’t willingly humbles him-ſelfe to the determination of Iustice: yet had he framed to himselfe (by the instruction of his frailty) manie de-ceyuing promises of life, which I (by my good leisure) haue discredited to him, and now is he resolu’d to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue paid the heauens your Function, and the prisoner the verie debt of your Calling. I haue la-bour’d for the poore Gentleman, to the extremest ſhore of my modestie, but my brother-Iustice haue I found ſo ſeuere, that he hath forc’d me to tell him, hee is indeede Iustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: If his owne life, Answere the ſtraitneſſe of his proceeding, It ſhall become him well: wherein if he chance to faile he hath ſentenc’d himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc
SPEECH.LINE: I am going to visit the prisoner, Fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace be with you.
He who the ſword of Heauen will beare,
Should be as holy, as ſeueare:
Patterne in himselfe to know,
Grace to ſtand, and Vertue go:
More, nor leſſe to others paying,
Then by ſelfe-offences weighing.
Shame to him, whose cruell ſtriking,
Kils for faults of his owne liking:
Twice trebble ſhame on Angelo,
To weede my vice, and let his grow.
Oh, what may Man within him hide,
Though Angel on the outward ſide?
How may likeneſſe made in crimes,
Making practise on the Times,
To draw with ydle Spiders ſtrings
Mo’t ponderous and ſubstantiall things?
Craft against vice, I must applie.
With Angelo to night ſhall lye
His old betroathed (but despised:)
So disguise ſhall by th’ disguised
Pay with falshood, false exacting,
And performe an olde contracting.
Take, oh take those lips away,
that ſo ſweetly were forsworne,
And those eyes: the breake of day
lights that doe mislead the Morne;
But my kiſſes bring againe, bring againe,
Seales of loue, but ſeal’d in vaine, ſeal’d in vaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake off thy ſong, and haste thee quick away,
Here comes a man of comfort, whose aduice
Hath often ſtill’d my brawling discontent.
I cry you mercie, Sir, and well could wish
You had not found me here ſo musicall.
Let me excuse me, and beleeue me ſo,
My mirth it much displeas’d, but pleas’d my wœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis good; though Musick oft hath ſuch a charme To make bad, good; and good prouoake to harme. I pray you tell me, hath any body enquir’d for mee here to day; much vpon this time haue I promis’d here to meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue not bin enquir’d after: I haue ſat here all day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe constantly beleeue you: the time is come euen now. I ſhall craue your forbearance a little, may be I will call vpon you anone for ſome aduantage to your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar
SPEECH.LINE: I am alwayes bound to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well met, and well come:
What is the newes from this good Deputie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath a Garden circummur’d with Bricke,
Whose westerne ſide is with a Vineyard back't;
And to that Vineyard is a planched gate,
That makes his opening with this bigger Key:
This other doth command a little doore,
Which from the Vineyard to the Garden leades,
There haue I made my promise, vpon the
Heauy midle of the night, to call vpon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: But ſhall you on your knowledge find this way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue t'ane a due, and wary note vpon't,
With whispering, and mo’t guiltie diligence,
In action all of precept, he did ſhow me
The way twice ore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Are there no other tokens
Betweene you 'greed, concerning her obseruance?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: No: none but onely a repaire ith' darke,
And that I haue poſſest him, my mo’t ſtay
Can be but briefe: for I haue made him know,
I haue a Seruant comes with me along
That ſtaies vpon me; whose perswasion is,
I come about my Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well borne vp.
I haue not yet made knowne to Mariana
A word of this: what hoa, within; come forth,
I pray you be acquainted with this Maid,
She comes to doe you good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe desire the like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you perswade your ſelfe that I respect you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Frier, I know you do, and haue found it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Take then this your companion by the hand
Who hath a ſtorie readie for your eare:
I ſhall attend your leisure, but make haste
The vaporous night approaches.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar
SPEECH.LINE: Wilt please you walke aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Place, and greatnes: millions of false eies
Are ſtucke vpon thee: volumes of report
Run with these false, and mo’t contrarious Quest
Vpon thy doings: thousand escapes of wit
Make thee the father of their idle dreame,
And racke thee in their fancies. Welcome, how agreed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Shee'll take the enterprize vpon her father,
If you aduise it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not my consent,
But my entreaty too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Little haue you to ſay
When you depart from him, but ſoft and low,
Remember now my brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Feare me not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor gentle daughter, feare you not at all:
He is your husband on a pre-contract:
To bring you thus together ‘tis no ſinne,
Sith that the Iustice of your title to him
Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let vs goe,
Our Corne's to reape, for yet our Tithes to ſow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither ſirha; can you cut off a mans head?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If the man be a Bachelor Sir, I can:
But if he be a married man, he's his wiues head,
And I can neuer cut off a womans head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, leaue me your ſnatches, and yeeld mee a direct answere. To morrow morning are to die Clau-dio and Barnardine: heere is in our prison a common exe-cutioner, who in his office lacks a helper, if you will take it on you to aſſist him, it ſhall redeeme you from your Gyues: if not, you ſhall haue your full time of imprison-ment, and your deliuerance with an vnpittied whipping; for you haue beene a notorious bawd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I haue beene an vnlawfull bawd, time out of minde, but yet I will bee content to be a lawfull hang-man: I would bee glad to receiue ſome instruction from my fellow partner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa, Abhorson: where's Abhorson there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Doe you call ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirha, here's a fellow will helpe you to morrow in your execution: if you thinke it meet, compound with him by the yeere, and let him abide here with you, if not, vse him for the present, and dismiſſe him, hee cannot plead his estimation with you: he hath beene a Bawd.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: A Bawd Sir? fie vpon him, he will discredit our mysterie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe too Sir, you waigh equallie: a feather will turne the Scale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray ſir, by your good fauor: for ſurely ſir, a good fauor you haue, but that you haue a hanging look: Doe you call ſir, your occupation a Mysterie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: I Sir, a Misterie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Painting Sir, I haue heard ſay, is a Misterie; and your Whores ſir, being members of my occupation, v-sing painting, do proue my Occupation, a Misterie: but what Misterie there ſhould be in hanging, if I ſhould be hang’d, I cannot imagine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, it is a Misterie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Proofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Euerie true mans apparrell fits your Theefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be too little for your theefe, your true man thinkes it bigge enough. If it bee too bigge for your Theefe, your Theefe thinkes it little enough: So euerie true mans apparrell fits your Theefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you agreed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I will ſerue him: For I do finde your Hang-man is a more penitent Trade then your Bawd: he doth oftner aske forgiueneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſirrah, prouide your blocke and your Axe to morrow, foure a clocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on (Bawd) I will instruct thee in my
Trade: follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I do desire to learne ſir: and I hope, if you haue occasion to vse me for your owne turne, you ſhall finde me y'are. For truly ſir, for your kindneſſe, I owe you a good turne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Call hether Barnardine and Claudio:
Th’ one has my pitie; not a iot the other,
Being a Murtherer, though he were my brother.
Looke, here's the Warrant Claudio, for thy death,
‘Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to morrow
Thou must be made immortall. Where's Barnardine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cla.
SPEECH.LINE: As fast lock’d vp in ſleepe, as guiltleſſe labour,
When it lies ſtarkely in the Trauellers bones,
He will not wake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Who can do good on him?
Well, go, prepare your ſelfe. But harke, what noise?
Heauen giue your ſpirits comfort: by, and by,
I hope it is ſome pardon, or repreeue
For the mo’t gentle Claudio. Welcome Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: The best, and wholsomst ſpirits of the night,
Inuellop you, good Prouost: who call’d heere of late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: None ſince the Curphew rung.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Not Isabell?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: They will then er't be long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: What comfort is for Claudio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: There's ſome in hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a bitter Deputie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo, not ſo: his life is paralel’d
Euen with the ſtroke and line of his great Iustice:
He doth with holie abstinence ſubdue
That in himselfe, which he ſpurres on his powre
To qualifie in others: were he meal’d with that
Which he corrects, then were he tirrannous,
But this being ſo, he's iust. Now are they come.
This is a gentle Prouost, ſildome when
The ſteeled Gaoler is the friend of men:
How now? what noise? That ſpirit's poſſest with hast,
That wounds th’ vnsisting Posterne with these ſtrokes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: There he must ſtay vntil the Officer
Arise to let him in: he is call’d vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you no countermand for Claudio yet?
But he must die to morrow?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: None Sir, none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: As neere the dawning Prouost, as it is,
You ſhall heare more ere Morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Happely
You ſomething know: yet I beleeue there comes
No countermand: no ſuch example haue we:
Besides, vpon the verie ſiege of Iustice,
Lord Angelo hath to the publike eare
Profest the contrarie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: This is his Lords man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: And heere comes Claudio's pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord hath ſent you this note,
And by mee this further charge;
That you ſwerue not from the ſmallest Article of it,
Neither in time, matter, or other circumstance.
Good morrow: for as I take it, it is almost day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall obey him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: This is his Pardon purchas’d by ſuch ſin,
For which the Pardoner himselfe is in:
Hence hath offence his quicke celeritie,
When it is borne in high Authority.
When Vice makes Mercie; Mercie's ſo extended,
That for the faults loue, is th’ offender friended.
Now Sir, what newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I told you:
Lord Angelo (be-like) thinking me remiſſe
In mine Office, awakens mee
With this vnwonted putting on, methinks ſtrangely:
For he hath not vs’d it before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you let's heare. The Letter. Whatsœuer you may heare to the contrary, let Claudio be ex-ecuted by foure of the clocke, and in the afternoone Bernar-dine: For my better ſatisfaction, let mee haue Claudios head ſent me by fiue. Let this be duely performed with a thought that more depends on it, then we must yet deliuer. Thus faile not to doe your Office, as you will answere it at your perill. What ſay you to this Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: What is that Barnardine, who is to be execu-ted in th’ afternoone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: A Bohemian borne: But here nurst vp & bred,
One that is a prisoner nine yeeres old.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: How came it, that the absent Duke had not either deliuer’d him to his libertie, or executed him? I haue heard it was euer his manner to do ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: His friends ſtill wrought Repreeues for him:
And indeed his fact till now in the gouernment of Lord
Angelo, came not to an vndoubtfull proofe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: It is now apparant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t manifest, and not denied by himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath he borne himselfe penitently in prison?
How ſeemes he to be touch’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: A man that apprehends death no more dread-fully, but as a drunken ſleepe, careleſſe, wreakleſſe, and feareleſſe of what’s past, present, or to come: insensible of mortality, and desperately mortall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: He wants aduice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: He wil heare none: he hath euermore had the li-berty of the prison: giue him leaue to escape hence, hee would not. Drunke many times a day, if not many daies entirely drunke. We haue verie oft awak’d him, as if to carrie him to execution, and ſhew’d him a ſeeming war-rant for it, it hath not moued him at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: More of him anon: There is written in your brow Prouost, honesty and constancie; if I reade it not truly, my ancient ſkill beguiles me: but in the boldnes of my cunning, I will lay my ſelfe in hazard: Claudio, whom heere you haue warrant to execute, is no greater forfeit to the Law, then Angelo who hath ſentenc’d him. To make you vnderstand this in a manifested effect, I craue but foure daies respit: for the which, you are to do me both a present, and a dangerous courtesie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray Sir, in what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: In the delaying death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, how may I do it? Hauing the houre li-mited, and an expreſſe command, vnder penaltie, to de-liuer his head in the view of Angelo? I may make my case as Claudio's, to croſſe this in the ſmallest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: By the vow of mine Order, I warrant you,
If my instructions may be your guide,
Let this Barnardine be this morning executed,
And his head borne to Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Angelo hath ſeene them both,
And will discouer the fauour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, death's a great disguiser, and you may adde to it; Shaue the head, and tie the beard, and ſay it was the desire of the penitent to be ſo bar’de before his death: you know the course is common. If any thing fall to you vpon this, more then thankes and good for-tune, by the Saint whom I profeſſe, I will plead against it with my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me, good Father, it is against my oath.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Were you ſworne to the Duke, or to the De-putie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: To him, and to his Substitutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: You will thinke you haue made no offence, if the Duke auouch the iustice of your dealing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: But what likelihood is in that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a resemblance, but a certainty; yet ſince I ſee you fearfull, that neither my coate, integrity, nor perswasion, can with ease attempt you, I wil go further then I meant, to plucke all feares out of you. Looke you Sir, heere is the hand and Seale of the Duke: you know the Charracter I doubt not, and the Signet is not ſtrange to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: I know them both.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: The Contents of this, is the returne of the Duke; you ſhall anon ouer-reade it at your pleasure: where you ſhall finde within these two daies, he wil be heere. This is a thing that Angelo knowes not, for hee this very day receiues letters of ſtrange tenor, perchance of the Dukes death, perchance entering into ſome Mo-nasterie, but by chance nothing of what is writ. Looke, th’ vnfolding Starre calles vp the Shepheard; put not your ſelfe into amazement, how these things ſhould be; all difficulties are but easie when they are knowne. Call your executioner, and off with Barnardines head: I will giue him a present ſhrift, and aduise him for a better place. Yet you are amaz’d, but this ſhall absolutely re-solue you: Come away, it is almost cleere dawne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I am as well acquainted heere, as I was in our house of profeſſion: one would thinke it were Mistris Ouer-dons owne house, for heere be manie of her olde Customers. First, here's yong Mr Rash, hee's in for a commoditie of browne paper, and olde Ginger, nine ſcore and ſeuenteene pounds, of which hee made fiue Markes readie money: marrie then, Ginger was not much in request, for the olde Women were all dead. Then is there heere one Mr Caper, at the ſuite of Master Three-Pile the Mercer, for ſome foure ſuites of Peach-colour’d Satten, which now peaches him a beggar. Then haue we heere, yong Dizie, and yong Mr Deepe-vow, and Mr Copperspurre, and Mr Starue-Lackey the Ra-pier and dagger man, and yong Drop-heire that kild lu-stie Pudding, and Mr Forthlight the Tilter, and braue Mr Shootie the great Traueller, and wilde Halfe-Canne that ſtabb’d Pots, and I thinke fortie more, all great doers in our Trade, and are now for the Lords ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Mr Barnardine, you must rise and be hang’d,
Mr Barnardine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa Barnardine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: A pox o'your throats: who makes that noyse there? What are you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Your friends Sir, the Hangman:
You must be ſo good Sir to rise, and be put to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Away you Rogue, away, I am ſleepie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell him he must awake,
And that quickly too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray Master Barnardine, awake till you are ex-ecuted, and ſleepe afterwards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ab.
SPEECH.LINE: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: He is comming Sir, he is comming: I heare his
Straw ruſſle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Is the Axe vpon the blocke, ſirrah?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie readie Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Abhorson?
What's the newes with you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly Sir, I would desire you to clap into your prayers: for looke you, the Warrants come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: You Rogue, I haue bin drinking all night,
I am not fitted for't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, the better Sir: for he that drinkes all night, and is hanged betimes in the morning, may ſleepe the ſounder all the next day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abh.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke you Sir, heere comes your ghostly Fa-ther: do we iest now thinke you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, induced by my charitie, and hearing how hastily you are to depart, I am come to aduise you, Comfort you, and pray with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Friar, not I: I haue bin drinking hard all night, and I will haue more time to prepare mee, or they ſhall beat out my braines with billets: I will not consent to die this day, that’s certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſir, you must: and therefore I beseech you
Looke forward on the iournie you ſhall go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſweare I will not die to day for anie mans per-swasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: But heare you:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a word: if you haue anie thing to ſay to me, come to my Ward: for thence will not I to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnfit to liue, or die: oh grauell heart.
After him (Fellowes) bring him to the blocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Sir, how do you finde the prisoner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: A creature vnpre-par’d, vnmeet for death,
And to transport him in the minde he is,
Were damnable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere in the prison, Father,
There died this morning of a cruell Feauor,
One Ragozine, a mo’t notorious Pirate,
A man of Claudio's yeares: his beard, and head
Iust of his colour. What if we do omit
This Reprobate, til he were wel enclin’d,
And ſatisfie the Deputie with the visage
Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, ‘tis an accident that heauen prouides:
Dispatch it presently, the houre drawes on
Prefixt by Angelo: See this be done,
And ſent according to command, whiles I
Perswade this rude wretch willingly to die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: This ſhall be done (good Father) presently:
But Barnardine must die this afternoone,
And how ſhall we continue Claudio,
To ſaue me from the danger that might come,
If he were knowne aliue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Let this be done,
Put them in ſecret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio,
Ere twice the Sun hath made his iournall greeting
To yond generation, you ſhal finde
Your ſafetie manifested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro
SPEECH.LINE: I am your free dependant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Quicke, dispatch, and ſend the head to Angelo
Now wil I write Letters to Angelo,
(The Prouost he ſhal beare them) whose contents
Shal witneſſe to him I am neere at home:
And that by great Iniunctions I am bound
To enter publikely: him Ile desire
To meet me at the consecrated Fount,
A League below the Citie: and from thence,
By cold gradation, and weale-ballanc’d forme.
We ſhal proceed with Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is the head, Ile carrie it my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Conuenient is it: Make a ſwift returne,
For I would commune with you of ſuch things,
That want no eare but yours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro
SPEECH.LINE: Ile make all ſpeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace hoa, be heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: The tongue of Isabell. She's come to know,
If yet her brothers pardon be come hither:
But I will keepe her ignorant of her good,
To make her heauenly comforts of dispaire,
When it is least expected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoa, by your leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Good morning to you, faire, and gracious daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: The better giuen me by ſo holy a man,
Hath yet the Deputie ſent my brothers pardon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath releasd him, Isabell, from the world,
His head is off, and ſent to Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but it is not ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: It is no other,
Shew your wisedome daughter in your close patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, I wil to him, and plucke out his eies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhal not be admitted to his ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Vnhappie Claudio, wretched Isabell,
Iniurious world, mo’t damned Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: This nor hurts him, nor profits you a iot,
Forbeare it therefore, giue your cause to heauen.
Marke what I ſay, which you ſhal finde
By euery ſillable a faithful veritie.
The Duke comes home to morrow: nay drie your eyes,
One of our Couent, and his Confeſſor
Giues me this instance: Already he hath carried
Notice to Escalus and Angelo,
Who do prepare to meete him at the gates,
There to giue vp their powre: If you can pace your wis-dome,
In that good path that I would wish it go,
And you ſhal haue your bosome on this wretch,
Grace of the Duke, reuenges to your heart,
And general Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: I am directed by you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: This Letter then to Friar Peter giue,
‘Tis that he ſent me of the Dukes returne:
Say, by this token, I desire his companie
At Mariana's house to night. Her cause, and yours
Ile perfect him withall, and he ſhal bring you
Before the Duke; and to the head of Angelo
Accuse him home and home. For my poore ſelfe,
I am combined by a ſacred Vow,
And ſhall be absent. Wend you with this Letter:
Command these fretting waters from your eies
With a light heart; trust not my holie Order
If I peruert your course: whose heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Good' euen;
Frier, where's the Prouost?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Not within Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh prettie Isabella, I am pale at mine heart, to ſee thine eyes ſo red: thou must be patient; I am faine to dine and ſup with water and bran: I dare not for my head fill my belly. One fruitful Meale would ſet mee too't: but they ſay the Duke will be heere to Morrow. By my troth Isabell I lou’d thy brother, if the olde fan-tastical Duke of darke corners had bene at home, he had liued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, the Duke is marueilous little beholding to your reports, but the best is, he liues not in them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Friar, thou knowest not the Duke ſo wel as I do: he's a better woodman then thou tak'st him for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: you'l anſwer this one day. Fare ye well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay tarrie, Ile go along with thee,
I can tel thee pretty tales of the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: You haue told me too many of him already ſir if they be true: if not true, none were enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SPEECH.LINE: I was once before him for getting a Wench with childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you ſuch a thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes marrie did I; but I was faine to forswear it,
They would else haue married me to the rotten Medler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir your company is fairer then honeſt, rest you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucio.
SPEECH.LINE: By my troth Ile go with thee to the lanes end: if baudy talke offend you, wee'l haue very litle of it: nay Friar, I am a kind of Burre, I ſhal ſticke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Euery Letter he hath writ, hath disuouch’d other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: In mo’t vneuen and distracted manner, his actions ſhow much like to madneſſe, pray heauen his wisedome bee not tainted: and why meet him at the gates and de-liuer our authorities there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I gheſſe not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: And why ſhould wee proclaime it in an howre before his entring, that if any craue redreſſe of iniustice, they ſhould exhibit their petitions in the ſtreet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhowes his reason for that: to haue a dispatch of Complaints, and to deliuer vs from deuices heere-after, which ſhall then haue no power to ſtand against vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: I beseech you let it bee proclaim’d be-times i'th’ morne, Ile call you at your house: giue notice to ſuch men of ſort and ſuite as are to meete him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall ſir: fareyouwell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Good night.
This deede vnshapes me quite, makes me vnpregnant
And dull to all proceedings. A deflowred maid,
And by an eminent body, that enforc’d
The Law against it? But that her tender ſhame
Will not proclaime against her maiden loſſe,
How might ſhe tongue me? yet reason dares her no,
For my Authority beares of a credent bulke,
That no particular ſcandall once can touch
But it confounds the breather. He ſhould haue liu’d,
Saue that his riotous youth with dangerous ſense
Might in the times to come haue ta'ne reuenge
By ſo receiuing a dishonor’d life
With ransome of ſuch ſhame: would yet he had liued.
Alack, when once our grace we haue forgot,
Nothing goes right, we would, and we would not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: These Letters at fit time deliuer me,
The Prouost knowes our purpose and our plot,
The matter being a foote, keepe your instruction
And hold you euer to our ſpeciall drift,
Though ſometimes you doe blench from this to that
As cause doth minister: Goe call at Flauia's house,
And tell him where I ſtay: giue the like notice
To Valencius, Rowland, and to Craſſus,
And bid them bring the Trumpets to the gate:
But ſend me Flauius first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſpeeded well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I thank thee Varrius, thou hast made good hast,
Come, we will walke: There's other of our friends
Will greet vs heere anon: my gentle Varrius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: To ſpeake ſo indirectly I am loath,
I would ſay the truth, but to accuse him ſo
That is your part, yet I am aduis’d to doe it,
He ſaies, to vaile full purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Be rul’d by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Besides he tells me, that if peraduenture
He ſpeake against me on the aduerse ſide,
I ſhould not thinke it ſtrange, for ‘tis a physicke
That's bitter, to ſweet end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: I would Frier Peter

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh peace, the Frier is come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: Come I haue found you out a ſtand mo’t fit,
Where you may haue ſuch vantage on the Duke
He ſhall not paſſe you:
Twice haue the Trumpets ſounded.
The generous, and grauest Citizens
Haue hent the gates, and very neere vpon
The Duke is entring:
Therefore hence away.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Duke, Varrius, Lords, Angelo, Esculus, Lucio, Citizens at ſeuerall doores

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: My very worthy Cosen, fairely met,
Our old, and faithfull friend, we are glad to ſee you.
Ang. Esc.
Happy returne be to your royall grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Many and harty thankings to you both:
We haue made enquiry of you, and we heare
Such goodneſſe of your Iustice, that our ſoule
Cannot but yeeld you forth to publique thankes
Forerunning more requitall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: You make my bonds ſtill greater.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh your desert ſpeaks loud, & I ſhould wrong it
To locke it in the wards of couert bosome
When it deserues with characters of braſſe
A forted residence 'gainst the tooth of time,
And razure of obliuion: Giue we your hand
And let the Subiect ſee, to make them know
That outward curtesies would faine proclaime
Fauours that keepe within: Come Escalus,
You must walke by vs, on our other hand:
And good ſupporters are you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: Now is your time
Speake loud, and kneele before him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Iustice, O royall Duke, vaile your regard
Vpon a wrong’d (I would faine haue ſaid a Maid)
Oh worthy Prince, dishonor not your eye
By throwing it on any other obiect,
Till you haue heard me, in my true complaint,
And giuen me Iustice, Iustice, Iustice, Iustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Relate your wrongs;
In what, by whom? be briefe:
Here is Lord Angelo ſhall giue you Iustice,
Reueale your ſelfe to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh worthy Duke,
You bid me ſeeke redemption of the diuell,
Heare me your ſelfe: for that which I must ſpeake
Must either punish me, not being beleeu’d,
Or wring redreſſe from you:
Heare me: oh heare me, heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, her wits I feare me are not firme:
She hath bin a ſuitor to me, for her Brother
Cut off by course of Iustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: By course of Iustice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſhe will ſpeake mo’t bitterly, and ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t ſtrange: but yet mo’t truely wil I ſpeake,
That Angelo's forsworne, is it not ſtrange?
That Angelo's a murtherer, is't not ſtrange?
That Angelo is an adulterous thiefe,
An hypocrite, a virgin violator,
Is it not ſtrange? and ſtrange?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay it is ten times ſtrange?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not truer he is Angelo,
Then this is all as true, as it is ſtrange;
Nay, it is ten times true, for truth is truth
To th’ end of reckning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Away with her: poore ſoule
She ſpeakes this, in th’ infirmity of ſence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Prince, I coniure thee, as thou beleeu'st
There is another comfort, then this world,
That thou neglect me not, with that opinion
That I am touch’d with madneſſe: make not impoſſible
That which but ſeemes vnlike, ‘tis not impoſſible
But one, the wickedst caitiffe on the ground
May ſeeme as ſhie, as graue, as iust, as absolute:
As Angelo, euen ſo may Angelo
In all his dreſſings, caracts, titles, formes,
Be an arch-villaine: Beleeue it, royall Prince
If he be leſſe, he's nothing, but he's more,
Had I more name for badneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: By mine honesty
If ſhe be mad, as I beleeue no other,
Her madneſſe hath the oddest frame of ſense,
Such a dependancy of thing, on thing,
As ere I heard in madneſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh gracious Duke
Harpe not on that; nor do not banish reason
For inequality, but let your reason ſerue
To make the truth appeare, where it ſeemes hid,
And hide the false ſeemes true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Many that are not mad
Haue ſure more lacke of reason:
What would you ſay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I am the Sister of one Claudio,
Condemnd vpon the Act of Fornication
To loose his head, condemn’d by Angelo,
I, (in probation of a Sisterhood)
Was ſent to by my Brother; one Lucio
As then the Meſſenger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That's I, and't like your Grace:
I came to her from Claudio, and desir’d her,
To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo,
For her poore Brothers pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: That's he indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: You were not bid to ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: No, my good Lord,
Nor wish’d to hold my peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I wish you now then,
Pray you take note of it: and when you haue
A busineſſe for your ſelfe: pray heauen you then
Be perfect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant your honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: The warrant's for your ſelfe: take heede to't.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: This Gentleman told ſomewhat of my Tale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: It may be right, but you are i'the wrong
To ſpeake before your time: proceed,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I went
To this pernicious Caitiffe Deputie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: That's ſomewhat madly ſpoken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon it,
The phrase is to the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Mended againe: the matter: proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: In briefe, to ſet the needleſſe proceſſe by:
How I perswaded, how I praid, and kneel’d,
How he refeld me, and how I replide
(For this was of much length) the vild conclusion
I now begin with griefe, and ſhame to vtter.
He would not, but by gift of my chaste body
To his concupiscible intemperate lust
Release my brother; and after much debatement,
My ſisterly remorse, confutes mine honour,
And I did yeeld to him: But the next morne betimes,
His purpose ſurfetting, he ſends a warrant
For my poore brothers head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: This is mo’t likely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh that it were as like as it is true.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen (fond wretch) y knowst not what thou ſpeak'st,
Or else thou art ſuborn’d against his honor
In hatefull practise: first his Integritie
Stands without blemish: next it imports no reason,
That with ſuch vehemency he ſhould pursue
Faults proper to himselfe: if he had ſo offended
He would haue waigh’d thy brother by himselfe,
And not haue cut him off: ſome one hath ſet you on:
Confeſſe the truth, and ſay by whose aduice
Thou cam'st heere to complaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: And is this all?
Then oh you bleſſed Ministers aboue
Keepe me in patience, and with ripened time
Vnfold the euill, which is heere wrapt vp
In countenance: heauen ſhield your Grace from wœ,
As I thus wrong’d, hence vnbeleeued goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I know you'ld faine be gone: An Officer:
To prison with her: Shall we thus permit
A blasting and a ſcandalous breath to fall,
On him ſo neere vs? This needs must be a practise:
Who knew of your intent and comming hither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isa.
SPEECH.LINE: One that I would were heere, Frier Lodowick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: A ghostly Father, belike:
Who knowes that Lodowicke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I know him, ‘tis a medling Fryer,
I doe not like the man: had he been Lay my Lord,
For certaine words he ſpake against your Grace
In your retirment, I had ſwing’d him ſoundly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Words against mee? this' a good Fryer belike
And to ſet on this wretched woman here
Against our Substitute: Let this Fryer be found.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: But yesternight my Lord, ſhe and that Fryer
I ſaw them at the prison: a ſawcy Fryar,
A very ſcuruy fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: Bleſſed be your Royall Grace:
I haue ſtood by my Lord, and I haue heard
Your royall eare abus’d: first hath this woman
Mo’t wrongfully accus’d your Substitute,
Who is as free from touch, or ſoyle with her
As ſhe from one vngot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: We did beleeue no leſſe.
Know you that Frier Lodowick that ſhe ſpeakes of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him for a man diuine and holy,
Not ſcuruy, nor a temporary medler
As he's reported by this Gentleman:
And on my trust, a man that neuer yet
Did (as he vouches) mis-report your Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, mo’t villanously, beleeue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: he in time may come to cleere himselfe;
But at this instant he is ſicke, my Lord:
Of a ſtrange Feauor: vpon his meere request
Being come to knowledge, that there was complaint
Intended 'gainst Lord Angelo, came I hether
To ſpeake as from his mouth, what he doth know
Is true, and false: And what he with his oath
And all probation will make vp full cleare
Whensœuer he's conuented: First for this woman,
To iustifie this worthy Noble man
So vulgarly and personally accus’d,
Her ſhall you heare disproued to her eyes,
Till ſhe her ſelfe confeſſe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Frier, let's heare it:
Doe you not ſmile at this, Lord Angelo?
Oh heauen, the vanity of wretched fooles.
Giue vs ſome ſeates, Come cosen Angelo,
In this I'll be impartiall: be you Iudge
Of your owne Cause: Is this the Witnes Frier?
First, let her ſhew your face, and after, ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon my Lord, I will not ſhew my face
Vntill my husband bid me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: What, are you married?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you a Maid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: A Widow then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Why you are nothing then: neither Maid, Wi-dow, nor Wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, ſhe may be a Puncke: for many of them, are neither Maid, Widow, nor Wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Silence that fellow: I would he had ſome cause to prattle for himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I doe confeſſe I nere was married,
And I confeſſe besides, I am no Maid,
I haue known my husband, yet my husband
Knowes not, that euer he knew me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: He was drunk then, my Lord, it can be no better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: For the benefit of ſilence, would thou wert ſo to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: This is no witneſſe for Lord Angelo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Now I come to't, my Lord.
Shee that accuses him of Fornication,
In ſelfe-ſame manner, doth accuse my husband,
And charges him, my Lord, with ſuch a time,
When I'le depose I had him in mine Armes
With all th’ effect of Loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Charges ſhe moe then me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Not that I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: No? you ſay your husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Why iust, my Lord, and that is Angelo,
Who thinkes he knowes, that he nere knew my body,
But knows, he thinkes, that he knowes Isabels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: This is a ſtrange abuse: Let's ſee thy face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: My husband bids me, now I will vnmaske.
This is that face, thou cruell Angelo
Which once thou ſworst, was worth the looking on:
This is the hand, which with a vowd contract
Was fast belockt in thine: This is the body
That tooke away the match from Isabell,
And did ſupply thee at thy garden-house
In her Imagin’d person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you this woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Carnallie ſhe ſaies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Sirha, no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Enough my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I must confeſſe, I know this woman,
And fiue yeres ſince there was ſome ſpeech of marriage
Betwixt my ſelfe, and her: which was broke off,
Partly for that her promis’d proportions
Came ſhort of Composition: But in chiefe
For that her reputation was dis-valued
In leuitie: Since which time of fiue yeres
I neuer ſpake with her, ſaw her, nor heard from her
Vpon my faith, and honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Noble Prince,
As there comes light from heauen, and words fro[m] breath,
As there is ſence in truth, and truth in vertue,
I am affianced this mans wife, as ſtrongly
As words could make vp vowes: And my good Lord,
But Tuesday night last gon, in's garden house,
He knew me as a wife. As this is true,
Let me in ſafety raise me from my knees,
Or else for euer be confixed here
A Marble Monument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I did but ſmile till now,
Now, good my Lord, giue me the ſcope of Iustice,
My patience here is touch’d: I doe perceiue
These poore informall women, are no more
But instruments of ſome more mightier member
That ſets them on. Let me haue way, my Lord
To finde this practise out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I, with my heart,
And punish them to your height of pleasure.
Thou foolish Frier, and thou pernicious woman
Compact with her that’s gone: thinkst thou, thy oathes,
Though they would ſwear downe each particular Saint,
Were testimonies against his worth, and credit
That's ſeald in approbation? you, Lord Escalus
Sit with my Cozen, lend him your kinde paines
To finde out this abuse, whence ‘tis deriu’d.
There is another Frier that ſet them on,
Let him be ſent for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peter.
SPEECH.LINE: Would he were here, my Lord, for he indeed
Hath ſet the women on to this Complaint;
Your Prouost knowes the place where he abides,
And he may fetch him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe, doe it instantly:
And you, my noble and well-warranted Cosen
Whom it concernes to heare this matter forth,
Doe with your iniuries as ſeemes you best
In any chastisement; I for a while
Will leaue you; but ſtir not you till you haue
Well determin’d vpon these Slanderers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, wee'll doe it throughly: Signior Lu-cio, did not you ſay you knew that Frier Lodowick to be a dishonest person?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Cucullus non facit Monachum, honeſt in nothing but in his Clothes, and one that hath ſpoke mo’t villa-nous ſpeeches of the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall intreat you to abide heere till he come, and inforce them against him: we ſhall finde this Frier a notable fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: As any in Vienna, on my word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Call that ſame Isabell here once againe, I would ſpeake with her: pray you, my Lord, giue mee leaue to question, you ſhall ſee how Ile handle her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Not better then he, by her owne report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry ſir, I thinke, if you handled her priuately She would ſooner confeſſe, perchance publikely ſhe'll be asham’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I will goe darkely to worke with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: That's the way: for women are light at mid-night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on Mistris, here's a Gentlewoman,
Denies all that you haue ſaid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, here comes the rascall I ſpoke of,
Here, with the Prouost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: In very good time: ſpeake not you to him, till we call vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Mum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Sir, did you ſet these women on to ſlan-der
Lord Angelo? they haue confes’d you did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis false.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: How? Know you where you are?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Respect to your great place; and let the diuell
Be ſometime honour’d, for his burning throne.
Where is the Duke? ‘tis he ſhould heare me ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke's in vs: and we will heare you ſpeake,
Looke you ſpeake iustly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Boldly, at least. But oh poore ſoules,
Come you to ſeeke the Lamb here of the Fox;
Good night to your redreſſe: Is the Duke gone?
Then is your cause gone too: The Duke's vniust,
Thus to retort your manifest Appeale,
And put your triall in the villaines mouth,
Which here you come to accuse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the rascall: this is he I ſpoke of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Why thou vnreuerend, and vnhallowed Fryer:
Is't not enough thou hast ſuborn’d these women,
To accuse this worthy man? but in foule mouth,
And in the witneſſe of his proper eare,
To call him villaine; and then to glance from him,
To th’ Duke himselfe, to taxe him with Iniustice?
Take him hence; to th’ racke with him: we'll towze you
Ioynt by ioynt, but we will know his purpose:
What? vniust?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not ſo hot: the Duke dare
No more ſtretch this finger of mine, then he
Dare racke his owne: his Subiect am I not,
Nor here Prouinciall: My busineſſe in this State
Made me a looker on here in Vienna,
Where I haue ſeene corruption boyle and bubble,
Till it ore-run the Stew: Lawes, for all faults,
But faults ſo countenanc’d, that the ſtrong Statutes
Stand like the forfeites in a Barbers ſhop,
As much in mocke, as marke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Slander to th’ State:
Away with him to prison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: What can you vouch against him Signior Lucio?
Is this the man you did tell vs of?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis he, my Lord: come hither goodman bald-pate, doe you know me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I remember you Sir, by the ſound of your voice,
I met you at the Prison, in the absence of the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, did you ſo? and do you remember what you ſaid of the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t notedly Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you ſo Sir: And was the Duke a flesh-mon-ger, a foole, and a coward, as you then reported him to be?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: You must (Sir) change persons with me, ere you make that my report: you indeede ſpoke ſo of him, and much more, much worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh thou damnable fellow: did I not plucke thee by the nose, for thy ſpeeches?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I protest, I loue the Duke, as I loue my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Harke how the villaine would close now, after his treasonable abuses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: Such a fellow is not to be talk’d withall: Away with him to prison: Where is the Prouost? away with him to prison: lay bolts enough vpon him: let him ſpeak no more: away with those Giglets too, and with the o-ther confederate companion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay Sir, ſtay a while.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: What, resists he? helpe him Lucio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſir, come ſir, come ſir: foh ſir, why you bald-pated lying rascall: you must be hooded must you? ſhow your knaues visage with a poxe to you: ſhow your ſheepe-biting face, and be hang’d an houre: Will't not off?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art the first knaue, that ere mad'st a Duke.
First Prouost, let me bayle these gentle three:
Sneake not away Sir, for the Fryer, and you,
Must haue a word anon: lay hold on him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: This may proue worse then hanging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: What you haue ſpoke, I pardon: ſit you downe,
We'll borrow place of him; Sir, by your leaue:
Ha'st thou or word, or wit, or impudence,
That yet can doe thee office? If thou ha'st
Rely vpon it, till my tale be heard,
And hold no longer out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, my dread Lord,
I ſhould be guiltier then my guiltineſſe,
To thinke I can be vndiscerneable,
When I perceiue your grace, like powre diuine,
Hath look’d vpon my paſſes. Then good Prince,
No longer Seſſion hold vpon my ſhame,
But let my Triall, be mine owne Confeſſion:
Immediate ſentence then, and ſequent death,
Is all the grace I beg.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither Mariana,
Say: was't thou ere contracted to this woman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I was my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe take her hence, and marry her instantly.
Doe you the office (Fryer) which consummate,
Returne him here againe: goe with him Prouost.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I am more amaz’d at his dishonor,
Then at the ſtrangeneſſe of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither Isabell,
Your Frier is now your Prince: As I was then
Aduertysing, and holy to your busineſſe,
(Not changing heart with habit) I am ſtill,
Atturnied at your ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh giue me pardon
That I, your vaſſaile, haue imploid, and pain’d
Your vnknowne Soueraigntie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: You are pardon’d Isabell:
And now, deere Maide, be you as free to vs.
Your Brothers death I know ſits at your heart:
And you may maruaile, why I obscur’d my ſelfe,
Labouring to ſaue his life: and would not rather
Make rash remonstrance of my hidden powre,
Then let him ſo be lost: oh mo’t kinde Maid,
It was the ſwift celeritie of his death,
Which I did thinke, with ſlower foot came on,
That brain’d my purpose: but peace be with him,
That life is better life past fearing death,
Then that which liues to feare: make it your comfort,
So happy is your Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: I doe my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: For this new-maried man, approaching here,
Whose ſalt imagination yet hath wrong’d
Your well defended honor: you must pardon
For Mariana's ſake: But as he adiudg’d your Brother,
Being criminall, in double violation
Of ſacred Chastitie, and of promise-breach,
Thereon dependant for your Brothers life,
The very mercy of the Law cries out
Mo’t audible, euen from his proper tongue.
An Angelo for Claudio, death for death:
Haste ſtill paies haste, and leasure, answers leasure;
Like doth quit like, and Measure ſtill for Measure:
Then Angelo, thy fault's thus manifested;
Which though thou would'st deny, denies thee vantage.
We doe condemne thee to the very Blocke
Where Claudio ſtoop’d to death, and with like haste.
Away with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my mo’t gracious Lord,
I hope you will not mocke me with a husband?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: It is your husband mock't you with a husband,
Consenting to the ſafe-guard of your honor,
I thought your marriage fit: else Imputation,
For that he knew you, might reproach your life,
And choake your good to come: For his Poſſeſſions,
Although by confutation they are ours;
We doe en-state, and widow you with all,
To buy you a better husband.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my deere Lord,
I craue no other, nor no better man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer craue him, we are definitiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentle my Liege.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: You doe but loose your labour.
Away with him to death: Now Sir, to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my good Lord, ſweet Isabell, take my part,
Lend me your knees, and all my life to come,
I'll lend you all my life to doe you ſeruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Against all ſence you doe importune her,
Should ſhe kneele downe, in mercie of this fact,
Her Brothers ghoſt, his paued bed would breake,
And take her hence in horror.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Isabell:
Sweet Isabel, doe yet but kneele by me,
Hold vp your hands, ſay nothing: I'll ſpeake all.
They ſay best men are moulded out of faults,
And for the mo’t, become much more the better
For being a little bad: So may my husband.
Oh Isabel: will you not lend a knee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: He dies for Claudio's death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Isab.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t bounteous Sir.
Looke if it please you, on this man condemn’d,
As if my Brother liu’d: I partly thinke,
A due ſinceritie gouerned his deedes,
Till he did looke on me: Since it is ſo,
Let him not die: my Brother had but Iustice,
In that he did the thing for which he dide.
For Angelo, his Act did not ore-take his bad intent,
And must be buried but as an intent
That perish’d by the way: thoughts are no ſubiects
Intents, but meerely thoughts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Meerely my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: Your ſuite's vnprofitable: ſtand vp I ſay:
I haue bethought me of another fault.
Prouost, how came it Claudio was beheaded
At an vnusuall howre?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: It was commanded ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Had you a ſpeciall warrant for the deed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord: it was by priuate meſſage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: For which I doe discharge you of your office,
Giue vp your keyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: Pardon me, noble Lord,
I thought it was a fault, but knew it not,
Yet did repent me after more aduice,
For testimony whereof, one in the prison
That ſhould by priuate order else haue dide,
I haue reseru’d aliue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: What's he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: His name is Barnardine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I would thou hadst done ſo by Claudio:
Goe fetch him hither, let me looke vpon him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Esc.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry, one ſo learned, and ſo wise
As you, Lord Angelo, haue ſtil appear’d,
Should ſlip ſo groſſelie, both in the heat of bloud
And lacke of temper’d iudgement afterward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ang.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorrie, that ſuch ſorrow I procure,
And ſo deepe ſticks it in my penitent heart,
That I craue death more willingly then mercy,
‘Tis my deseruing, and I doe entreat it.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Barnardine and Prouost, Claudio, Iulietta.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Which is that Barnardine?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: This my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: There was a Friar told me of this man.
Sirha, thou art ſaid to haue a ſtubborne ſoule
That apprehends no further then this world,
And ſquar'st thy life according: Thou'rt condemn’d,
But for those earthly faults, I quit them all,
And pray thee take this mercie to prouide
For better times to come: Frier aduise him,
I leaue him to your hand. What muffeld fellow's that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pro.
SPEECH.LINE: This is another prisoner that I ſau’d,
Who ſhould haue di’d when Claudio lost his head,
As like almost to Claudio, as himselfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: If he be like your brother, for his ſake
Is he pardon’d, and for your louelie ſake
Giue me your hand, and ſay you will be mine,
He is my brother too: But fitter time for that:
By this Lord Angelo perceiues he's ſafe,
Methinkes I ſee a quickning in his eye:
Well Angelo, your euill quits you well.
Looke that you loue your wife: her worth, worth yours
I finde an apt remiſſion in my ſelfe:
And yet heere's one in place I cannot pardon,
You ſirha, that knew me for a foole, a Coward,
One all of Luxurie, an aſſe, a mad man:
Wherein haue I ſo deseru’d of you
That you extoll me thus?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: 'Faith my Lord, I ſpoke it but according to the trick: if you will hang me for it you may: but I had ra-ther it would please you, I might be whipt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Whipt first, ſir, and hang’d after. Proclaime it Prouost round about the Citie, If any woman wrong’d by this lewd fellow (As I haue heard him ſweare himselfe there's one whom he begot with childe) let her appeare, And he ſhall marry her: the nuptiall finish’d, Let him be whipt and hang’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: I beseech your Highneſſe doe not marry me to a Whore: your Highneſſe ſaid euen now I made you a Duke, good my Lord do not recompence me, in making me a Cuckold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine honor thou ſhalt marrie her.
Thy ſlanders I forgiue, and therewithall
Remit thy other forfeits: take him to prison,
And ſee our pleasure herein executed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Luc.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrying a punke my Lord, is preſſing to death,
Whipping and hanging.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Slandering a Prince deserues it.
She Claudio that you wrong’d, looke you restore.
Ioy to you Mariana, loue her Angelo:
I haue confes’d her, and I know her vertue.
Thanks good friend, Escalus, for thy much goodneſſe,
There's more behinde that is more gratulate.
Thanks Prouost for thy care, and ſecrecie,
We ſhall imploy thee in a worthier place.
Forgiue him Angelo, that brought you home
The head of Ragozine for Claudio's,
Th’ offence pardons it ſelfe. Deere Isabell,
I haue a motion much imports your good,
Whereto if you'll a willing eare incline;
What's mine is yours, and what is yours is mine.
So bring vs to our Pallace, where wee'll ſhow
What's yet behinde, that meete you all ſhould know.

PERSONAE.PERSONA: The names of all the Actors.
